You won't find better "bang for the buck" at this price point.First the good:(1)  It is very inexpensive; you'll be hard-pressed to find so many features at this price in other low-end cameras.(2)  Construction quality is very good; the camera seems sturdy and well-built.(3)  WiFi range is excellent - I am having no problems getting a good image anywhere in my house.(4)  PTZ gives you almost 360 degrees of view if you rotate from one extreme to the other.(5)  The built-in infrared diodes are bright enough to easily illuminate an entire room for nighttime viewing.(6)  You get a nice screw-in mount and a convenient retractable Ethernet cable bundled with the camera.Now the not-so-good:(1)  The camera lens has significant "fish eye" distortion.(2)  With a 640 x 480 pixel resolution, you're not going to be getting a good picture of an intruder's face unless he gets fairly near the camera in good lighting conditions.  If you need a higher-resolution image, you're going to have to spend more money on a better camera.(3)  The effective frame rate is not that high - maybe 3 to 5 fps if you're watching an image from outside your home network.(4)  The audio quality from the built-in speaker and microphone is adequate, but not very impressive.  You can hear what's going on through the camera, and be understood at the other end, but it's like talking through a long stovepipe.  On the other hand, it is more than adequate for a baby monitor.(5)  It is a pain to set up unless you know what you're doing.Fortunately, at least for Mac users, it's not that hard to configure it once you know the trick.  Here is what to do, assuming you have a Mac laptop and a wireless home router with at least one free Ethernet port:(1)  Copy over FOSCAM's "IP Camera Tool" app onto your Mac.  You can either copy it from the bundled CD, or download it from the FOSCAM site.(2)  Now open System Preferences on your Mac, and click on the Network icon.  When the network window opens, click on the Wi-Fi tab (if it's not already selected) and click the "Advanced" button in the lower right hand corner of the window.(3)  In the new window that appears, click the "TCP/IP" tab.  Write down the Subnet Mask and Router IP addresses, and then close System Preferences window.(4)  Now here's the tricky part:  you have to decide which IP address on your router you want to reserve for the camera.  For example, if your Router IP address is 10.0.1.1, you'll want to change the last number to use as your camera IP address, e.g. 10.0.1.61 or 10.0.1.100 for the camera.  However, you don't want to re-use an existing address that the router has already allocated.  You have two choices:  either log in to your router and check which addresses are being currently allocated, or just pick a number between 2 and 255 at random, e.g. 10.0.1.61, and see if it works.  Obviously these numbers may be different depending on the router.  For example, if your Router IP address is 192.68.2.1, then you can try 192.68.2.61 or 196.68.2.100 for the camera.(5)  Turn off your Mac's Wi-Fi connection.  Plug the camera into your Mac's Ethernet port using the supplied cable, but don't connect the camera's AC adapter yet.(6)  Start the IP Camera Tool app.  An empty window will open on your desktop.  Now turn on the camera by plugging in its AC adapter.  After about 20 seconds, the camera will begin to rotate through its start-up sequence.  At that point, you'll get several socket error warnings from the IP Camera Tool.  Click through these errors, and you'll finally get back to the IP Camera Tool window, which will show an Anonymous device (this is the camera) with an incorrect subnet error message, asking you to double-click to fix it.(7)  When you double-click the message in the window, a small window will open.  For the IP address, fill in the address you've chosen for your camera.  For the Subnet Mask, use the same number you wrote down earlier.  For Gateway and DNS Server, fill in the Router IP address you wrote down earlier.(8)  Leave the password field blank, with user "admin".  Click OK.(9)  The camera will restart.  After it has restarted, you'll start getting socket error warnings again.  Ignore them, unplug the camera, and quit the IP Camera Tool app.(10)  Now use the Ethernet cable to plug the camera into an unused Ethernet port on your router.  Plug in the AC adapter and wait for the camera to restart.(11)  Turn on your laptop's WiFi again.  Open the Safari browser and type in the IP address you chose for the camera, e.g. the http prefix followed by 10.0.1.61.(12)  If you did everything right, you'll be able to log in to the camera's built-in web server and configure it using the Device Management tab.  Specifically, you can scan for a wireless network list under "Wireless LAN Settings", select your own home network, enter the password, and click the box labeled "Using Wireless LAN".  Click Submit and the camera will restart again.(13)  Now unplug the camera from the router.  Again, use your Safari browser to access the IP address of the camera (you may have to close and re-open the Safari window).  If your wireless connection is working, you'll be able to log in to the camera again, and make any other configuration changes that you want.If you want to use your camera outside of your home network, you'll need to learn about port forwarding.  I won't go into that, because it is dependent on the router, but for my cameras I use port 80 for the internal port of each camera, and ports 8101 through 8104 for my external ports, respectively.  It works fine, and I can watch my home over my iPhone without any difficulty.As a final note, I strongly recommend that you buy the Foscam Pro app for your iPhone / iPad.  The same app will work for both (you only need to buy it once), and it will give you complete control over the camera, including access to the audio features.

Reviews.Title: Good all-around IP cam
Reviews.Author: MFR2VCB
Reviews.Content: Compared to the FI8918W, the color quality is better. I setup my camera to work with sensr.net which allows me to automatically upload images to their site via FTP which in my situation works perfectly because the satellite internet connection is too slow to support live video.

Reviews.Title: IR cut triggers too often
Reviews.Author: Scott
Reviews.Content: Cons:-----1) IR Cut filter is too sensitive.  Slightest variance in room light causes it to flake out, on-off-on-off-on and you end up with false alarms, etc.  Not to mention a clicking sound when it turns on and off.2) The IR lights are visible.  A good IR camera doesn't bleed into the visible spectrum so much.3) Worse, there is a faint green light inside the housing that cannot be turned off.  It blinks frequently and can be seen through the camera shell.4) Web software doesn't work well, Active-X based, or requires browser support.  You'd think they'd be using HTML5 by now.5) Sound is really faint to non-existent.  Definitely will need a separate audio baby monitor to complement.6) Doesn't seem to support HTTPS.7) I have had no luck pointing it outside through a window.  The IR reflection makes it impossible -- I'm not sure if it's my windows or what.Pros:-----1) Easy setup with 3rd party software.  I don't even use the built-in crap, but everything else I have tried works great.2) Easy to share.  I poked a hole in my firewall, and was all set, as I already have Dynamic DNS and no need for the camera to do it for me.  Not sure what the complaining is about, but then I work in IT.3) Windows Phone app that supports it.If there was something else on the market, I'd get it.  I'm not sure there is, unfortunately.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera - easy wireless - not so easy internet viewing
Reviews.Author: Talie
Reviews.Content: UPDATE: we have been using the camera for a month now. It works really well. My initial troubles of viewing over the Internet were solved and I am very happy with the camera. Added a star because of the great performance.I have been using the camera for three days. Overall I am pleased with the camera because of the good quality picture, pan/tilt feature, and low price.Pros- Inexpensive (compared to most cameras with the same features)- Very good picture- IR works well- Easy setup on wireless network- There is a free app for the iPhone to view and control the camera (CamViewer for Foscam)Cons- Setup for internet viewing is difficult. DDNS provider documented in setup manual is no longer free :( I had to search out an alternative. I used [...]. I'm not sure how well my alternative will work because I have dynamic IP address. (if this part of the review confuses you, beware of setting this camera up).-Built-in web server viewer isn't functional with iPhone or iPad (doesn't respond to touch). There is a free app available as a substitute (see above)- Sound does not work with browsers other than Internet Explorer (the recommended plug-in for Chrome and Firefox didn't work for me).- Sound will not work on iPhone or iPad (my research so far hasn't revealed a way to get it to work)

Reviews.Title: Foscam Tech support
Reviews.Author: Jim Weinkauf
Reviews.Content: Camera itself works as it should and does the job. I am pretty good at computers, not an expert, but above average. Big problem is set up and customer service. Instructions are very poor. The sole reason I purchased was for security to view from out of town. Initial set up was easy for viewing in home, but once I got to the viewing over internet it became a major mess. I could not get it to work and it was impossible to contact Tech support or customer service. After sending several emails and dozens of times trying to phone over several days, I got lucky and had someone answer the phone. They wanted to charge me $39.95 to help set up even tho I bought it straight from them. After debating that, and saying then that I would like to just return it, they agreed to link into my computer and set it up for remote viewing. It worked for a day and quit. I tried to get it working again unseccessfully so spent the next 5 days trying again to reach them. I finally got thru, and they reset it up and then told me that it wouldn't continue to work unless I used the dyndns service because I didn't have a static IP on my router. Now...going that route I discovered that the dyndns service they show in all their information, their website, and instructions as free...is not free at all. It gives you a 14 day trial period and then costs after that.Conclusion...if you are VERY knowledgeable about port forwarding, IP addresses, gateway, DNS servers, etc, etc, etc, the unit works well. However, if you are not VERY familiar with those things, the set up is very difficult, the instructions are very poor, and plan on not being able to get ahold of assistance of replies to emails.I finally requested to return the unit and they refused. Good product if you can get it to work, but VERY, VERY bad people to work with for assistance and customer assistance.

Reviews.Title: Great Baby Monitor
Reviews.Author: Christopher Tran
Reviews.Content: I'm an expecting new dad shopping around for a video monitor. My sister recommended the Motorola MBP36 that she's been using. This and the the Summer Infant Infant model seem to be the mostly highly regarded. But I really liked the idea of being able to view from anywhere, on iPhones, iPads and Android. (I currently have an iPad and a Samsung Galaxy Note). I had found the Samsung SmartCam Baby Monitor at Target.  So I thought I'd give it a try before spending the big bucks for those with dedicated monitors. I was disappointed in it's performance and features so it was returned after just a few days.Speaking to a couple of friends, I was warned against units with dedicated displays.  The displays often degrade over time because of the lower quality TFT LCD screens.So I did a bit more research and tried something not even advertised as a "Baby Monitor". The Foscam FI8910W. It a IP Camera with excellent features and performance. Once I tried this, it was day and night. The setup is more geeky. To view the feed from the internet, you'll have to know how to setup your router for port mapping and have either a static IP or Dynamic DNS. But for a person like me who deals with this stuff all the time, it was quite simple, no trial and error. Either you know how to do it or you don't. You're streaming directly from the Camera so there's no delay and the video quality, although not HD (there's also an HD version the FI9820W but never tried this), is fantastic! The night time performance is awesome. It supports Pan and Tilt, but not Zoom (some software will allow digital zoom, but this is pretty useless). On my iPad it looks amazing, way better than even the Motorola unit. Same on my Galaxy Note and any of my computers. The video doesn't degrade when you're connected from outside you home network. The two-way audio, although not fantastic is more than acceptable. It's bigger unit, but it doesn't take up much more room than the Samsung, which is flat. The biggest plus, it's less than $90 on Amazon. So while I wait for my wife to pop, I'm using the camera to monitor my Dog while I'm at work. I've even been able to get his attention when he's up to no-good while I'm at the office.Pros-Great Video quality and frame-rate-Fantastic PanTilt performance-Fantastic Night performance, LEDs come on automatically as needed.-Audio performance is more than adequate.-Built-In Streaming server that you can setup with various Viewer Apps on difference platforms (PC, MAC, IOS and Android)-LAN and Wifi ConnectionCons-Internet viewing setup can be a bit much for those not familiar with port mapping, static external IP or DDNS.  It might also be a bit challenging for some to locate the initial IP address, although there's a small application avaiable on the CD to discover it.  You should assign a fixed IP for the Camera on your router to avoid having to do this again.-Doesn't have Optical Zoom (not a huge Con since the video quality is sharp enough for decent detail)(Part of this review was from my review of the Samsung SmartCam baby monitor)

Reviews.Title: simply doesn't work, terrible tech support
Reviews.Author: Nathan L.
Reviews.Content: I purchased many of these cameras planning to equip my facility for security, but couldn't get just one to work.  Called tech support 7 times, but only got to talk to a live technical person once with heavy accent who didn't have the knowledge to help me setting up FTP connect and promised to call me back, but didn't.  This has been the worst experience I have gone through with any vendor... hands down.

Reviews.Title: Foscam Support - No Help
Reviews.Author: David
Reviews.Content: I have to agree with many other reviewers, despite website promises of customer support if purchased directly from Foscam, I have found that it's almost impossible to contact or get help from their supposed "support". The documentation is terrible too. Very disappointing.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera.  Simply performs as advertised
Reviews.Author: Mike
Reviews.Content: Lets get the bad out of the way first:  Foscam's documentation is a joke.  It's terrible.  This camera will do everything they say it can, but you kind of have to figure it out for yourself.  Foscam's documentation will get you started, but that's about it.  **THEREFORE, IF YOU ARE NOT TECHNICALLY PROFICIENT OR FAMILIAR WITH BASIC NETWORK ARCHITECTURE & PROTOCOLS THE ADVANCED FEATURES OF THIS CAMERA WILL BE TOUGH FOR YOU TO SETUP.**On to the good:  The basic stuff this camera is supposed to do - connect quickly to your wireless network, pan/tilt/zoom, capture great images in regular and little/no light at reasonable distances - just works, it's fantastic.  The applications available for viewing the video on your iOS or Android device are all over the map, more on this later, but initial setup was a breeze and, again, it just works.  The advanced features, such as motion sensing, the ability to email you a picture, save a picture or video stream and forward all such traffic outside your wireless LAN to the interwebs at large also just work.  These advanced features took a little while to setup and again, if you're not familiar with port forwarding and dynamic DNS hosting services then this stuff will be difficult for you.  I am an experienced user and it took me a couple hours to make it all work.  Some of that time was spent hunting around for better documentation though because, again, Foscam's documentation sucks, but once I got it, it was awesome.Recommended Mobile Application:  THIS IS IMPORTANT so I'm surprised there is less commentary out there on which mobile app is the best.  Your mobile app is primarily how you are going to view the video stream, at least that's true for me so the app you choose affects how many of the camera's features you can enjoy.  I tried a couple but BY FAR the best one out there, at least for iOS is LiveCams Pro (available here: [...]).  A buddy of mine - a very advanced user who has an Android device - uses the same and I actually thought the Android interface was a little more robust and easier to use.Final Analysis:  We bought this as a baby monitor but after seeing all that it will do I'm buying at least 2 or 3 more for home security purposes.  I am VERY impressed with this little thing's skills.  I highly recommend this for use either as a baby monitor or a security camera.

Reviews.Title: Understand What your buying, and know you need to understand Networks.
Reviews.Author: Darped
Reviews.Content: I am getting tired of all these reviewers bashing these foscam cameras.  the prodcut works, and if you know nothing about the industry and cant tell the difference between analog cctv camera setups vs IP based setups dont bother buying this product.I have installed approximately 100 fi8918's fi8905's, and these over the last year w/ minimal effort and issues.  I do however understand static IP addressing, port forwarding, and other IP necessities to set these up.  I also know the next closest camera in price range with this featureset is ~$400.And the complaints about the built in web server.  Again i have used linksys/cisco cameras, dinks, and vivotek (high end ip cameras) and the built in monitoring software  all suck.  If you are planning on using this as a security setup and viewing from a computer BUY BLUE IRIS software.  I have this running security for several commercial security applications (and my customers love it).  and for android and iphone us IP cam viewer (from robert chou)  the best out there.and if all of this makes no sense to you, hire someone to do the install for you.  It takes a qualified profession about 4 minutes to configure each camera for your network...seriously, 4 minutes.if you dont understand the technology needed to make this work, DONT BUY and if you do buy, DONT CRITICIZE the product (since you dont understand it)Lastly, a baby monitor...seriously.  buy a summer infant baby video monitor..its your baby's safety.  I am an IT professional and would never dream of using any of these IP based systems as a dedicated baby monitor (you really need high quality audio for a baby monitor and alerts if the reciever loses connection from the remote device, IP cams offer none of that..)Thanks for listening

Reviews.Title: Very disappointing
Reviews.Author: Jewel
Reviews.Content: I could only get this to work with an ethernet connection. In the wireless mode, it is extremely difficult to set up. It requires professional help.

Reviews.Title: weak
Reviews.Author: Zachary P. Schneider
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera for security at my wife's store.It was complicated to setup. Looked huge and cumbersome when mounted. Mounting equipment was flimsy and weak. Picture had lag and was not the best resolution.requires a static ip to allow for iphone viewing or you will constantly have to update the ip in your mobile device.2 weeks later i gave up and bought 2 dropcams. What a world of difference. took no time to setup and i get 7 day dvd backup on a could server audio, video, and picture are 100x better.

Reviews.Title: disappointed consumer
Reviews.Author: Alex
Reviews.Content: It is rare that I take the time to review anything. I like to purchase things on amazon and mozy on my way continuing life.however, I will add that after reading a ton of these reviews, and then reading the subsequent comments questioning the validity of the reviews, I would have to question them myself.I bought the product, then, per their instructions, updated the firmware after setting it up.I followed all the videos and whatever else provided, setup the dns, and wireless, to access the camera away from home.shortly after I discovered that the firmware upgrade made the wifi connectivity sufferable at best. I can no longer get full resolution, which results in a tiny 320xsomething small like 160 screenshot, entirely useless for surveillance.I contacted foscam, and this was the response from tech support. broken english and all,"In the first, I doubted there was a reboot issue when light is too bright and the environment is very exquisite (light is very bright and has many grass and trees).In such a special environment, the picture size may beyond the DSP buffer and camera will reboot.However, you mention it will also happen at night.It may caused by the drop wifi issue, please wired connect it to have a test."basically, this 'amazing' tech support rep told me at first that the reflection of light and grass(detail in general) would cause the camera to have issues. He then tried to say it was due to the camera being outdoors.he finally settled on it being a connectivity issue due to the wireless...what is the point of buying a wireless camera if the wireless does not work?nonetheless, I ordered a replacement (quick service by amazon, running the ball on foscam's screwup), unfortunately, the replacement camera had even worse range...at 10-15 ft away, I would lose signal to the camera, even at the lower resolution.I was afraid to update the firmware on this, to make it possibly any worse.its a shame because the price is right, if the camera worked. I can even deal with the crappy mount. Just get better anchor/screw setup and you wont have any issues, that is, if you can get the camera to work with how you need it. I couldnt.foscam does offer a signal booster antenna, but based on the reviews, the signal booster is entirely useless as well. I think my ultimate resolution to this problem will be to return the new camera as well and go with another brand period.Foscam's reply to all of this, as a general statement, was that amazon sellers sell a 'knockoff', so they do not provide support..what a shame.its very rare that a product in the top 5 of any category happens to be so low quality..would not recommend this as a wireless camera at all..I guess it would be ok for wired purpose but then why spend the money towards a wireless camera at all?

Reviews.Title: Do Not Buy
Reviews.Author: ARN0LD_LAYNE
Reviews.Content: Do not buy these cameras as the new versions have numerous problems.  Their advice for after purchase support is to contact the retailer (Amazon) and they won't let you return them.  There is no support outside of China.One of mine reboots every time I try to change its position and the other keeps generating browser errors saying the camera can't be contacted.Lastly, judging by the nearly identical set of grammatical errors in the reviews, I think the good reviews were written by someone from Foscam.

Reviews.Title: Foscam 8910 as a Baby Monitor
Reviews.Author: David T. Woodhead "ukviewer"
Reviews.Content: Baby monitors cost too much, come with lousy screens and cameras and we can't see them on our smartphones, tablets or desktops. IPCamera could be the ultimate solution for someone looking for a flexible baby monitor, here is my experience:The Camera:* The picture quality is good for the cost, significantly better than the Summer Infant video monitor it was replacing* Dark picture quality is exceptional* The camera itself is larger than most packaged baby-cams though for us that didn't matter* The speaker in the camera is weak so sending audio to the camera is a gimmick that doesn't work well* The built in web monitoring tools are weak though you likely won't use them muchSetup:This is an IP Camera and does little or nothing to help the tech novice. If you know your way around a router and are willing to spend some time reading then it is easy enough to figure out (see the excellent info in the review from R.Tickle). To fully setup this camera you need to know how to do the following:* Log into your router to find the cameras IP address* Assign a static IP address* Setup port forwarding on your routerIf you don't know what those things and aren't interested in learning then then this may not be the product for you.As a baby monitor:The challenge here is finiding the right app for your device. For iOS "Baby Monitor for IP Camera" is perfect and will do everything your out of the box solution does and more. Android is a stickier problem to solve, "IP Cam Viewer Pro" seems to be the best option out there but it isn't ideal for things like overnight audio monitoring. I hope the options for both iOS and Android improve in the coming months and I expect they will.The advantages of having the monitor on all our "smart devices" (we use iPad, iPhone, Android and Kindle Fire) as well as the ability for me to see my little one wake up when I am at my desk at work are huge wins for me. You can also capture stills or video right to your device which is something I wish I had many times with the out of the box monitor. Overall I believe an IP Camera is the best monitoring solution for any tech savvy parent, the benefits massivley outweigh the downsides.ONE BIG DRAWBACK. Using an IP Camera means that the monitor is stuck at home or will need to be setup on another wireless network to make it work. If you plan to travel a lot with your child and want your monitor to travel with you then I would suggest buying a cheap audio only monitor to suppliment this. You can also use it to get around some of the Android app shortcomings for overnight audio monitoring and it gives you a decent travel option.

Reviews.Title: Best buy for the money
Reviews.Author: E. Martinson "Ladlenits"
Reviews.Content: I spent a lot of time looking for a good IP camera. My motivation to get a camera was to use it as a baby monitor, I was going to also hook this up to my Synology NAS DS 211 with surveillance station.Setup:I work in I.T. so I wasn't too worried about the setup as some people have complained about it. With that being said I felt it was very easy to set up and had the wireless and port forwarding setup in less than half an hour. Since I knew what I was doing in advance I cant remark on how difficult/easy the documentation is to read for a novice user in setting it up.Video Quality:I don't have much experience with IP cameras but I am very pleased with the video quality. I have seen cameras with similar specs selling for much more than this so for ~ $100 bucks you cant be too picky. The quality and detail it picked up is more than adequate for what I need. The night vision was great, In a large room and very low light I was able to pick up everything in its line of sight very clearly. The one thing I noticed that I've seen on other reviews was a faint clicking noise when the IR lamps were on.Other Features:I like that it also has a built in mic and speaker so i can pick up the sounds nearby and also transmit audio to the device. I've already freaked my wife out a few times with this. The pan tilt and zoom is great also. There are a few spots it cant rotate to and the digital zoom is just that so you lose a lot of quality when you zoom in. If you are going to be using this with a Synology Disk Station some of these features are not available through their surveillance station so be prepared for that. From the forums at Synology it looks like they are working on getting all the features enabled but it sounds like both Synology and Foscam blame each other for the things that don't work so im not holding my breath.Interface:The built in web interface is okay. Nothing to spectacular and I honestly didn't play around with it all that much. I will be doing most of my Live viewing from my iPhone or iPad so I use an app called LiveCamPro which is excellent and worth the money.All in all I think for what you get with this camera it is a bargain. If you need a camera with lots of features and good quality picture pick one of these up.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera at a good price, works just fine with Mac and Firefox
Reviews.Author: Techno Nerd
Reviews.Content: This is my second Foscam, my first is the model immediately preceding this one. Both were quick and easy to set up.I used Firefox on a Mac to do the setup. It works fine. You don't need to use the CD that comes with the camera at all.Login to your router and bring up the list of DHCP clients. Hook the camera up to your router (mine is a D-Link DIR-655) and plug in the power.  The camera is set up by default to use DHCP, so it will shortly appear in the router's list of clients. Make a note of that IP address, then open a new browser window and browse to the camera's IP. You'll get the camera's built-in web server. Firefox users need to be sure to select server push mode. Default login is username "admin" with no password. From there you can complete the setup, including changing to a static IP and getting it talking to your wireless. My wireless uses WPA2/AES security and the camera connected to it as soon as I saved the configuration settings.It took less than five minutes from opening the box to having it up and running on my wireless network.Please don't be put off by negative reviews written by people who lack even the tiny bit of technical knowledge needed to set up and configure this great little camera.

Reviews.Title: Terrible firmware
Reviews.Author: J. Adams
Reviews.Content: Keeping this brief. After using 2 of these cameras on my home network for the past 4 months, I have grown to hate them. The image is good and the sound works well in both directions.  However, every couple of weeks they just drop all connectivity to the network (wireless) and I have to do a factory reset and then figure out all over again how to get them to play nicely over wifi.  Foscam support says to give the cameras a static ip. I have done this and the problem persists.  The firmware for networking is just terrible and having to use the clunky software to get it on wifi every couple weeks is the end of the line for me.  I'll be looking for something else.

Reviews.Title: Great hardware, horrible software and instructions
Reviews.Author: Dr. Michael J. Storek
Reviews.Content: Clearly, the Foscam deserves five stars for the hardware- great picture quality, wide range of movements, quiet motor. Setting up the camera on my home network was relatively easy, but the pain starts if you want to view the picture outside of your home network. Not being an IT expert, i quickly hit the bottom of my knowledge and instruction manual and website were of ZERO help...let me try few more times and if I do not succeed, the camera goes back....Ok no luck after a week of intermittent trying - thus sending the cam back this week....

Reviews.Title: FOSCAM shipped half way repaired junk as "new"! Also, horrible Phone Support
Reviews.Author: 4mark2009
Reviews.Content: I purchased direct from FOSCAM.US the FI9826W and FI9806W in May 2014. The 9826 was obviously re-boxed, missing plastic wrap and smelled like it had been “on fire”, burnt microchip smell. The cam preset and other functions did not work.Calling FOSCAM for support was a nightmare. I tried 8 times, and spent 4 hrs 19 minutes on hold. Then, I never did get the needed assistance. The Foscam phone support tech hardly understood English as if I could understand anything he was saying on that broken voice over IP phone system they use.After all that, the phone technician finally told me I needed an RMA. But, I must send an email requesting replacement to: replacement@foscam.us. So, I sent them an email a few days ago. THEY HAVE NOT YET REPLIED. Looks like I will need to contact my Credit Card Company to get a refund. HORRIBLE!PRE-SALE QUESTIONS? GIVE UP! I called to ask if the FI8906W requires a 12v or 5v cable. I was on hold 97 minutes total. I was hung-up on my first call by a phone technician. SECOND CALL: The phone technician was guessing at an answer of 5volts. But, how can that be true when all the other outdoor cams are 12v to power 30-60 LEDs? Foscam support was guessing based on wrongly listed accessories on the 8906 web page. No answer was ever confirmed by Fascom. I got the correct “12 volt” answer from a YouTube video. I needed to be sure before purchasing 3x cables at 14.99 each. Foscam was wrong. HORRIBLE!AUDIO QUESTION? Do you want to know if the cam audio-in is line level or electorate microphone? GIVE UP, Foscam support can not answer. They will guess and cost you a lot of effort, time and, money.Who are these people that give this company good review? Could it be Foscam Public Relation posting lies? YES, all the reviews saying great support MUST BE a Foscam Public Relation Company posting propaganda!I will send my cams back and fight the charges with my credit card. Stick a fork in me, I’m done.

Reviews.Title: If you want a camera that works 25% of the time, then get this
Reviews.Author: candilw
Reviews.Content: Bought this to use as a baby monitor.  Setup took a bit longer than I'd like, but gets easier each time I perform a reset on the camera.  I've tried several differnet apps on my iphone, ipad, and old andriod phone. (I've spent over $20 on apps)  All experience the same thing, so I know it's the camera.  Sometimes it works great, but then connection will drop and it can take anywhere from 30-60 minutes to get a good connection again.  Then it drops again shortly afterwards, cycle repeats.  Rarely will this ever work for 60 straight minutes.  It's not consistent and provides no ease of mind, especially at night when I'm trying to sleep because I have no way of knowing it's not working without picking up my ipad or iphone.  I even bought a wifi repeater and tried using that.  Same issue.  When I called tech support, their simple answer is perform a hard reset (button on the bottom) even though I'd already done that.  I've tried google to find answers.  I've updated firmware, etc.  I'm not sure how this camera gets such good reviews. I'm also not sure how people keep saying tech support (and giving their name) was a great help.  Seems like bogus reviews if you ask me.  I was hoping this would work because I'm expecting another baby and wanted one for his room as well as my 2 year old.  I've been trying for 2 months to get this thing to work and I'm about ready to give up because I'm wasting too much time!

Reviews.Title: Good Tech support...?
Reviews.Author: Jennifer Veldhuizen "JennyJoy80"
Reviews.Content: I just got the camera today and tech support was very good and walked me thru the whole setup including remote access.  Frankly, he was pushy enough to ask me to write a review while he was linked into my computer via remote, thus watching and commenting about my review, (which I edited later) including telling me to write about the camera before I even got to try it and form an opinoin.  While he did everything and got it all working I was surprised that never asked me or mentioned that I should set up a password for my camera.He did his job which I appreciate but I still have negative/ creepy feeling about the whole thing. I don't know...

Reviews.Title: Constantly reboots
Reviews.Author: cb950 "cb950"
Reviews.Content: I'm not too impressed with this camera.  I expected it to work when 5 feet from an access point in the attic above.  It does, but as soon as there is much movement in the picture or a light turns on, it reboots itself.  when it powers back up you can usually connect, but it's almost too irritating to use even as a baby monitor.  Definitely not reliable enough to be used in any kind of surveillance application.  Granted a wired professional pan tilt zoom camera is going to be over $1000 so I guess you get what you pay for.

Reviews.Title: freezes up on certain scenes
Reviews.Author: Stephen Mitschke
Reviews.Content: I purchase this directly from Amazon Jan 2014.  There have been some reports that the camera will freeze on certain scenes.  Foscam posted a statement on their website that all were fixed.  Unfortunately, this is now the case.  This camera will freeze on certain images.  It's very reproducible.

Reviews.Title: 2 cameras with hardware defect!
Reviews.Author: geeebs
Reviews.Content: STAY AWAY from FOSCAM, scan these reviews to get information about the hardware failure of the cameras. I had problems with 2 of the cameras, after 2 hours on the phone waiting for 'customer support' I give up: back to Amazon they go.These cameras have a latent failure, and even though FOSCAM says that they have addressed all the issues by November 2013, they never did a recall so there is stock out there (that Amazon has) that is has the defect.STAY AWAY!

Reviews.Title: Ridiculously complex set up
Reviews.Author: Paul
Reviews.Content: Do you know your IP address? Do you know if your IP address if static or dynamic? If you can't answer these questions then you will probably be very frustrated in setting up remote access to this device. Asking the average user to reconfigure his/her router and manually type in IP addresses to configure a device is unacceptable in this day and age. I sent it back.

Reviews.Title: FOSCAM technical issues
Reviews.Author: antech
Reviews.Content: If you're running windows 8.1 the software will not work and Foscam support will tell you that the camera management software is having technical issues (bull****) and they suggest you use the browser access.  I bought the camera for the ability to tilt / pan and for the camera software that Foscam claimed it came with, if i wanted basic camera features i would have stayed with the two linksys cameras i had before. After speaking to the support tech who wanted to access my pc remotely to make it all work,  i was imformed that if i wanted i could purchase Foscam Blue Iris professional security cam software.  Really!!! Not happy with the advertising that Foscam gave this camera... they were just better off selling the camera with no software at all. If i cant get it to work i will be returning it and never buying another Foscam product again

Reviews.Title: Camera does not function with wireless after upgrading firmware
Reviews.Author: Dale R. Fordham "BG Prof"
Reviews.Content: I have had two different cameras, both of which had the firmware upgraded on them.  Since that upgrade, they lost their ability to see ANY wireless network. AVOID all Foscam product upgrades!  Other than that, the camera is fine.

Reviews.Title: Decent image quality, terrible motion detection, doctored reviews
Reviews.Author: Chris S.
Reviews.Content: So here's the real deal on the Foscam FI8910W:Motion detection is unfortunately a nightmare.  If you were hoping to use this as a security camera of sorts, emailing you when motion is detected in your garage/vacation home/shop, forget about it.  It can be adjusted, but there's also no feedback on the adjustment screen to let you know how much motion has been detected and if it would trigger an alert.I have two Foscams, one is an outdoor model that is currently crashed, and one is this indoor model.  I also have a Panasonic wifi camera that is the non-HD model.Setup is reasonable if you know how to connect to your router.  It's still a bit 1990's style, but other cameras like the Panasonics aren't really much easier.Feature-wise, however, the Foscams are very crude compared to the Panasonic cameras.  It can email you snapshots of motion detected, but don't expect to be able to configure various schedules and different types of alerts depending on the time of day, etc.Pros:Wifi range is goodPicture quality is so-soCons:Device firmware (software) is crude and rudimentaryFalse motion alarms galore.  This is a problem on both the indoor and outdoor modelsCheap and flimsy construction; pan and tilt is loose and jiggles, and position resets after a rebootFoscam customer service pressures users into posting five-star Amazon reviews (you'll even see this in some of the reviews), and who knows how many of these thousands of reviews are fakes posted by Foscam cronies?  This is not a five star product.

Reviews.Title: FOSCAM vs DROP
Reviews.Author: Peter
Reviews.Content: I've first bought  a Dropcam and returned it, and bought this Foscam. If you are in doubt between the 2, here's what you should know.Buy the DROPCAM if:1) you don't want to waist time on set up - it's play and play, and the FOSCAM asks you to configure DNS and other complicated stuff that a normal consumer should not have to worry about2) You just want to view the video from Ipad, Iphone or Android device. Their app works fine, but just for these devices, nothing more3) If you want the ability to ZOOM4) If you don't mind paying a subscription every month if you want to record the videosBuy the FOSCAM if you1) If you want to remotely rotate your camera and have a 360 view2) If you want to access the video from any device, any browser or PC, not just iOS and Android3) If you don't mind paying extra to configure a DNS (30 bucks per year)I chose the FOSCAM because I can control the camera remotely and if works with a variety of 3rd party apps on Windows devices. The set up is a nightmare, but the tutorial video gets you there if you have patience. Both cameras has a good night vision and alerts, and both cameras have 2 way audio (the speakers are bad in both, in the FOSCAM you have the option to plug your speakers and mic)

Reviews.Title: IP Cameras are the way to go - very worth the setup hassle
Reviews.Author: Jmac
Reviews.Content: Quick overview -After returning 2 cameras that I was trying to set up to use as a baby monitor, I finally found what I was looking for. Every other camera that tries to connect thru Wifi is slowwwwwwwwwww. It would take 10-15 seconds for the camera to pop up when I set up the far more expensive "Dropcam" when I was in my own home on the same network, and I believe they take up a ton of your bandwith. Foscam loads in an INSTANT from home. It seems to always be connected, making me feel much better unlike the other monitors that seem to connect whenever they feel like it. The image even loads in less than 5 seconds at my work guest server, which is the definition of INCREDIBLY slow. I was pretty amazed about that.Plus, Dropcam and other cameras had way way way less features in their app store as they only have THEIR app, it didn't pan/tilt, and they charged $10 a month if you wanted to record with it. And the notifications were terrible. Foscam has NUMEROUS apps on both Iphone and Droid, so you can test out many of them until you find the one that works for you (even has dedicated baby monitor apps with sound graphs and such). I use my old Droid phones as monitors now. Two-way talk works better than I think people give it credit, as the other 2 more expensive monitors I had sounded about the same or worse I thought. Plus, if you want, you can hook up a mini speaker to the camera since it even has audio jacks in the back.One thing I haven't heard people say - I thought the camera was pretty big. It was bigger than the others for sure (won't fit on a window sill), but it does come with a mount if you want to hang it on the wall somewhere. But, you can buy 2 for the price of 1 of the other ones, and I like how much it can pan around the room a lot more than I thought I would.Setup -For those that want to use this just to view when you are at home (like as a baby monitor), setup is a piece of cake. The install instructions have been updated it seems since many of the youtube postings (search "awkwardhamster foscam" and you'll find a ton of them), but they still help, so if you are feeling overwhelmed just watch those 15 min vids before doing anything and it will definitely help. To install from the CD, I clicked the 3rd folder (03_Central Management Software), then connected the camera power and ethernet cable, then opened the windows folder (01_For Windows OS) and it found my camera. Double click on it and follow the youtube video instructions to continue.As for setting it up to view from anywhere - yes, this was a royal pain in the arse. It SHOULD have been a lot easier as there are pretty good step by step instructions on how to do it via those youtube videos and even the instructions that come with it... however, for me, it just simply didn't work at first.The host site would just show it as not connected even after doing everything. After getting really pissed for about 20 minutes... POOF, the site just magically worked. At first I tried creating a no-ip.info address, and after that failed, the newer ones have their own website you can use if you enable it in the DDNS options. But... that one didn't work either.So I tried modifying like 30 different IP numbers, port forwarding numbers, changing passwords... all failing. Then, I don't even know what I did or how it happened, but I tried it again, and BOTH redirecting sites worked. I guess some of these server things just take time to load. I'd recommend creating the no-ip host site, set up the port forwarding numbers, then going out for dinner and coming back before trying anything.Other Camera Comparisons -Every other non-IP camera out there costs as much as it does because they try to make it "simple." Once you figure this one out, I find it even simpler. You just have to remember/write down a few IP numbers, create some passwords, and once you have it all, you can put them into your phone apps and forget about them for the time being. The thing that bothered me most with the other cameras is that none of their apps had a "sound bar" so that if the volume on my monitor is low, I could still see that the baby is crying because it would have those red bars showing up like a traditional monitor. IP cameras have plenty of apps that will do just that, and worlds more that I have yet to discover such as recording and taking pics and whatnot.I very much like my new toy, especially for under $100. The End.

Reviews.Title: Reboot issue still unfixed
Reviews.Author: Keepin' 'em honest
Reviews.Content: Recently there is a nasty bug with this and possibly other models of foscam cameras that causes it to constantly reboot when the image contains a lot of detail and/or bright light. Essentially this problem makes the camera unusable if you have it pointed outside in daylight, but depending on the image data it could affect other image subjects as well.It's still not clear if this will be able to be fixed, since foscam hasn't officially commented on the matter.Potential buyers, you might take a look in the foscam support forum to see if this has been resolved before you buy. If you use a search engine with "foscam technical support forum" you should be able to find the forum.I'll amend this review if this fatal flaw is fixed, but for now, minimum stars since I've been stuck with an unusable camera with no recourse from support.

Reviews.Title: Decent camera, gets the job done most of the time
Reviews.Author: A. McLeland
Reviews.Content: First, this will be a long review as I am including a setup tutorial below.Second, I don't believe most of the reviews on here are real. I'm pretty sure all of the reviews that call out specific customer service reps are fake. Those users only have reviews for one item - this camera.Now, on to this camera. I was looking at video monitors for my baby's room and was just baffled at how some companies could justify charging 2-300 dollars for a video monitoring system. I looked into network security cameras and settled on one I felt met my needs for a far lower price. I think the price they ask for this is fair.Notes:The plastic of the camera feels a bit cheap and flimsy, but once it is mounted, I am comfortable with it and sure there will not be a problemIt is larger than I expected it to be.The camera occasionally reboots for an unknown reason.I will say that this camera probably will not be easy to set up for a lot of people. I feel like you need to have a medium-high level of tech understanding to get this running on your own.Here is a detailed list of what I did to set up the camera which can be used as a tutorial. This is Windows specific.In-Home viewing (Inside my home network)- I ignored the CD that came with it. I find that most of the time the software provided by the company doesn't get in to the level of detail I prefer when setting these things up.- Plugged the camera in to the wall, then attached the provided network cable to the camera and my router.- Checked my router for the assigned I.P. address and MAC address of the camera- Entered the camera's I.P. address and port number (I believe it was 22) into my web browser (I use Chrome), a la xxx.xxx.xx.12:22.- Logged in as Admin and started going through settings.  - Clicked "Alias Settings" to change the camera name. I called mine BabyCam. When you are logged in to the camera, this will appear as the title in the tab you are viewing as "Device(BabyCam)".  - Date and Time settings. Set it to Central time and picked time.nist.gov as the time server to sync to.  - Users. I added two additional users, one for me and one for my wife. Note that you CAN NOT change the admin password when you are logged in as Admin!- Went back to my router and added a static I.P. for the camera. The exact process varies depending on the router you have, but the basic concept involves entering the MAC address of the camera and the static I.P. you want the device to have inside your network. I arbitrarily set the address to xxx.xxx.xx.49 and saved the setting, which restarts my router.- Disconnected then reconnected the power plug to the camera. This causes it to connect to the assigned I.P. address you just created.- Navigate to the new I.P. address you set up. In my case this is xxx.xxx.xx.49:22.  - Log in to the camera.  - Navigate to the "Basic Router Settings" tab.  - Uncheck the "Obtain IP from DHCP Server" box. We want to tell the camera which I.P. to use.  - In the "IP Addr" box, enter the I.P. you specified as static in your router settings.  - Enter your subnet mask. Most cases this is 255.255.255.0. To be sure, you can type "cmd" in the Search box of the Windows Start button to open a command prompt. Type "ipconfig" and hit enter. Subnet mask will be buried in the results, usually 4-6 lines from the top of the result output.  - Gateway and DNS Server should be set to your router's IP address.  - Enter a port number you want the camera to use. This can be any number, really. You don't want it to collide with anything else on your network, though, so pick something weird. I used the year of my birth and added a 1 to the end.  - Leave "Network Lamp" unchecked. Keeps that pesky green light on the back of the camera from flashing in your baby's room.  - Click "Submit". Your camera will restart. - Once the restart is complete, go to the Wireless LAN settings and set up your wireless router properties if you plan to use the camera on your wireless network. When you submit, the camera will restart again.- I ignored the ADSL, UPnP, and DDNS settings tabs. I set up dynamic DNS stuff on my own using [...]. Use the comment section if you want instructions on this.- I also ignored the rest of the settings. Since I am using this for a crib monitor I don't really want a zillion motion-detected pictures taken. Babies move a lot. ;-)To change Admin password, log out of the camera interface, then log back in as one of the new users you set up. Change the admin password, then save. Camera will reset.At this point you should be able to use the camera wirelessly anywhere in your house and access the camera feed from any device in your network by using a web browser and navigating to the camera's I.P. address and port number, logging in, and clicking "Live Video".For viewing on a mobile device, download one of many apps available in the Play store (I use an Android device). My app of choice is IP Cam Viewer Lite. This does not mean it is the best. :-)Good luck. Happy to answer questions in the comments section.

Reviews.Title: A great camera once you figure out how to get it all working
Reviews.Author: faltered
Reviews.Content: I am now running 4 of these in my home.  I wanted to jump in and write a review about all the discussion around this camera.First, yes, there are some fake reviews in here - its pretty obvious.  Shame on them and shame on Amazon for allowing it.  HOWEVER.....I got my first camera and it had a learning curve for installation.  Getting the camera to work is the easy part, remote viewing from your iPhone when not connected to your home network is another story..... BUT ITS ACTUALLY EASY ONCE YOU FIGURE IT OUT.I am dangerously tech savvy - but far from a pro, and now I could set up one of these cameras in 5 min.I will say, Focam recently did some set-up videos on their website that are really quite good.  If you follow that, you will be set-up in no time.Everytime I see these cameras go on sale, I want to get another.... but for now 4 is enough.

Reviews.Title: Very good low cost camera
Reviews.Author: Mondo "beyondo"
Reviews.Content: I've had a couple of these wifi IP cams and this one has been the best so far. You can't beat it for price vs features. Picture is great, color very good, pan/tilt works fine, night vision is good, and the two-way audio really does work. FYI, the two way is not full duplex (i.e. you can't hear while your talking, like on a phone) and there is a delay. Not perfect, but does the job. I tried hooking up a small external speaker, one of those mini, rechargable ones made for a tablet, got a lot of feed back/static, so gave that up (minus 1 star).You need to have some computer savy to set an IP camera up, it doesn't matter what brand you buy. If you don't know what an "IP" address is, or have trouble navigating router settings, you're going to need help.Also should mention this works great using an Iphone/Ipad app. There are several that work, Webcam pro works for me on the Ipad and was easy to setup.

Reviews.Title: It works well but don't expect plug and play setup
Reviews.Author: J. Gaspard "a very picky person"
Reviews.Content: Got this as a baby monitor, wifi set up was a minor pain, you will need to assign a static ip address on your router for the camera which is not explained in the included instructions. After that it works well. Image is clear, even night vision.Be aware that the IR led's emit a red light while in use, no big deal for this use (infant monitor) but keep that in mind.There are several apps both android and iOS that tie into this unit, I can move the camera, change modes all remotely from my phone and iPadThe only thing I would change would be to include a proper set of instructions, If you don't know much about messing around in your router settings you are going to have a long night getting this working properly.

Reviews.Title: Foscam FI8910W Not Worth The Headache
Reviews.Author: R. Mickley
Reviews.Content: This camera sounded great for simple indoor use, but the setup was a nightmare (and I build computers and am a tech geek).  After combing through various forums I was able to get everything working as desired, but the quick installation guide might as well be burned.  Go straight to the user manual that is on the included disc and good luck.  As I said, I had to do a great deal of searching on the internet to get the thing to work properly.

Reviews.Title: Warranty clarification
Reviews.Author: Kevin
Reviews.Content: I don't have this camera, and only rated it with the average of what others did because I had to give a rating.Another reviewer provided some misinformation about the warranty.  From Foscam's website:[...]"Please note: In order to receive FREE TELEPHONE TECHNICAL SUPPORT as well as our US Based 1 Year Replacement Warranty, you must purchase directly from Foscam.us or from one of our Authorized Dealers listed below. If you do not purchase from an authorized dealer, you will not receive technical support or our 1 year warranty. "Amazon.com is listed.

Reviews.Title: Avoid - Foscam employees rating their own product
Reviews.Author: Vegan Billy
Reviews.Content: They're gaming the system here on Amazon.  Look elsewhere and don't support such a conniving company.  I'm looking elsewhere now.  It's a shame because I would have purchased this camera without the gaming.

Reviews.Title: Won't stop restarting and panning
Reviews.Author: truenoob
Reviews.Content: I had very high hopes for this camera.  The picture quality is great.  I bought this to monitor a stationary subject.  Therefore I don't want/need a unit that pans.  The panning is great though because remotely I can adjust the angle just the way I want without having to run back and forth from the camera to my PC to get it just right.  The problem with this unit is that it won't stop rebooting.  Everytime it reboots, it will cycle through it's entire range by panning around (up, right, down, left, up).  This kept happening despite setting a preset to have it stay on a fixed position after reboot, which would be fine if it only rebooted once a day.  Sometimes this would reboot many times throughout the day. I searched the internet and found some "work arounds" which didn't work for me.  You can do your own search and see that this is a problem.  I'm returning this unit as I am just going to go with one that does not have the ability to pan.

Reviews.Title: Great camera - great price - so why only 1 star?
Reviews.Author: Amazonian "IR"
Reviews.Content: I have two of these and they are great easy to use cameras.  I found setup to be fairly straightforward and performance and image quality to be more than good enough, especially at this price point - so why only one star?Model FI8910W does not support https and has no way (without  separate software like BlueIris or setting up some separate SSL reverse proxy) of remote viewing without leaving all camera data unprotected.  I did not even realize https was not supported until I bought the cameras as I assumed this would be a standard feature.  It is irresponsible for Foscam to sell a camera where they advertise the ability to connect from anywhere with no provision to secure the data sent from the camera.The more expensive FI9821W HD model added https support with a firmware update and I remain hopeful Foscam will do the same with this model.  If that happens I will revise my review upward.

Reviews.Title: Best IP Cameras for price bar none
Reviews.Author: vardelda
Reviews.Content: Keeping this simple as there are many good reviews here with lots of detail:  Foscam makes the best budget cameras bar none.  I say from lots of experience:  No one else comes close.Setting up these cameras will annoy you.Talking to Foscam will annoy you.Eventually you'll have a hardware failure that will annoy you.Deal with it.  You can buy 4-5 of these for the price of the next best IP camera **and still not get any better results** -- excepting customer service.  Foscam does exceedingly poorly at that.  Again, just deal with it.Pros: - Cheap - Great performance - Great features - Great configurability - Best IR performance for cameras 4x in price -- monitor large rooms in the dark with no problem! - Great software support by PC, Mac and Android app vendors - DDNS set up is now automatic if you want it (a major improvement for non-techies)Cons: - No zoom - Internal IR sensor make an audible 'click' when light levels change and IR is activated/deactivated.  Internal IR sensor is overly sensitive and can cycle on & off multiple times when ambient light is changing (sun going down, etc.).  Combine the two and you can end up with a camera clicking annoyingly every 10-20 seconds for a few minutes. - Setup is annoying (but they are improving!) - Customer Support (but they are working on it - last two emails I sent not only got an answer (surprise!) but within 24 hours (major surprise!))Advice (IMPORTANT NOTE:  This is different, and **guaranteed** better, than several other recommendations I read): - Don't use DDNS.  Just pick a high IP address and leave them there.  Example:  If you have 1-100 active but only 10 devices connecting to your network.  Assign the camera to 95 and nothing will bother it.  -- If you do want a dynamic IP, Foscam now defaults to their own service which worked fine in my brief tests. - Turn off the Network Lamp in configuration -- its overly bright and draws attention to the camera.  (Electrical tape also works) - Don't set Patrol Speed to 0 or 1.  Its too fast to control on an app.  2 is the minimum with a fast connection.  3-4 is better. - Set up Mail Settings so you get notified when your IP address changes. - If you want these for Security, buy the Blue Iris software.  Tuning the Alarm sensitivities is an adventure you likely won't be fully happy with.  But it is tunable and, in the end, its only hard drive space so go for it! - Port forwarding is beyond the scope of this review.  But suffice it to say:  Every camera needs its OWN port -- even though the internal IPs are different.  Externally you will hit one IP:nnnn (assigned port number).  And if you have a guest network, DO NOT put any cameras on it.  They must all be on the home/base network!  You have been warned.

Reviews.Title: Reboot Problem
Reviews.Author: SoonerBoy
Reviews.Content: The Foscam fi8910w constantly would reboot one to five times a day.  After three weeks, I returned it for a refund.

Reviews.Title: IR Stopped working / Horrible Tech Support
Reviews.Author: t
Reviews.Content: The IR functionality on this camera stopped after 3 days.  I called the 800 number on the foscam.us website to try to troubleshoot it, but the guy who answered the phone did not have any desire to help troubleshoot or do anything useful.  Before he hung up on me, he told me that if I still had problems (duh--he didn't actually fix anything in the 3 minutes he talked to me), I could file a request for RMA from the website.  I've done that, and now I'm waiting.The product failed in the first week out of the box.  The tech support is not only worthless but rude.  I would never buy anything from foscom again.  I only wish I would've returned the product in the first 30 days to get a refund to buy something else.

Reviews.Title: Does everything I wanted . . . and more
Reviews.Author: Rich Miletic
Reviews.Content: I travel quite a bit so I was looking for a simple camera that was not too expensive to set up and control remotely and log images and video upon motion sensing.I did some research on the web and took the plunge and tried out this one. Setting up the basics to view video is simple. If you want the ability to view remotely you need to know something about Router port forwarding and IP address reserving. If you have a dynamic IP on your Router (most of us do) then I suggest signing up with a free DNS service so you never lose remote access if your ISP changes your IP. If you will be logging video and images then make sure you got enough hard drive space.I have it set up to upload images to my local FTP server upon motion (and/or audio trigger) alarm. I also have it set up to send me an email upon motion and/or audio alarm and to record video and save it to my local computer which I can log into and download from anywhere (via my own FTP server).I added the mobile phone Android App which works great. It allows me to watch live video and control the pan-tilt.The video quality is good at 640x480. If you want higher resolution you are going to have to pay $$. The video is great for its resolution day and night (has IR). The IR kicks in automatically and does a good job in the crossover light period too.The extra stuff it has is audio recording and two-way audio. It does work but I have yet to fully use these features but I will and will let you know.A couple of side notes. In order to utilize some of the features of this camera like video recording you need to use Internet Explorer and select the Active X control mode. It works with other browsers but some of the features don't show up. I found this out because I use Chrome and couldn't see how to record video upon alarm detection. I sent an email to Foscam and that evening they responded to my question telling me to use Active X in IE. Good service response albeit probably a question they get often.Also, don't use the CMS software they include on the CD. It is buggy (found one where it would crash the program), clunky and didn't really seem to work. I couldn't delete or edit a camera, strange. Anyway, it seems like this software is legacy stuff prior to the web-based apps. Stick to using IE with the Active X control mode.

Reviews.Title: PRODUCT SUCKS!
Reviews.Author: Sonya Pace
Reviews.Content: What a joke!I wish I had read thru the other reviws more closely.Camera was weird to set up for wi-fi- which is what I wanted it for, refuses to stay connected to our router- which handles 8 other items just fine, audio doesn't work when used as wireless, software is a joke- just wasted my time with this purchase. READ the reviews cause I sure wish I read ALL of them. My issues are simply repeats of everyone elses!!Just printed my return label and can't wait to seal this thing back in a box and get it on it's way to returns.

Reviews.Title: Foscam - Go from A to F if you deal with them.
Reviews.Author: JCS
Reviews.Content: I thought other reviewers must be exaggerating the negatives of Foscam Customer Service. Until I tried to deal with them on a faulty camera, by phone and email. Its definitely the worse company I have dealt with. A summary of what you can expect if you deal with them, step by step:Real and non-embellished account of my experience:A) Have broken camera (8920), known recently to be faulty, so email their tech as listed on their website asking for replacement;B) Call Foscam Customer Service after emails unanswered, be on hold for an hour and then speak to someone who cannot authorize anything substantive, and with whom it is very difficult to communicate basic information;C) Call another number and two days later get an email from them with a return authorization # which you pay for shipping on defective product;D) get an email three days after the return logged received at their company, asking me for $7 shipping to send a replacement camera back to me (objected but promised to pay to get it over with), promising they will bill me thru paypal and ship it right out;E) No billing in paypal, and therefore email and call them back twice to beg that they send the $7 billing (so the cam can ship), but the phone extension actually listed on their Customer Service person rings "not valid extension."F) Write this review and promise myself to never deal with the company again (even though I own 9 Foscams). Customer Beware, Just dont do it.*(of the 9 Foscams I own only 7 work properly, they have various quirks like the rotation does not work properly, etc, that I will just have to live with for now)

Reviews.Title: Poor build quality, and microphone is useless, but otherwise does the job
Reviews.Author: Doug H.
Reviews.Content: I ordered two of these cameras to use along with others for security/nanny observation.  The build quality of these cameras is about what you would expect for the price: flimsy and low-end.  The first of the two cameras works o.k., though the speaker is essentially a crackly, non-functional noisemaker.  The microphone pops and snaps, but it picks up enough for our purposes.  The camera does not adjust well to sunlit or shadowed rooms.  However, aside from this minor complaint, the video quality, particularly when using IR, is quite good for such an inexpensive camera, though.  It's not crystal-clear HD, but for $60, it serves its purpose.The second camera's microphone was completely non-functioning, and the speaker suffered with the same problems.  Support was a little slow to respond, but did not give us any trouble returning the unit.The software is definitely substandard compared to other cameras, but we use the IP Cam Viewer app by Robert Chou on iphone and Android instead, so this isn't a big issue.  Overall, you get what you pay for.  If you're expecting an amazing, highly functional camera with two-way audio for $60, you should adjust your expectations.  If you want a camera that works on a budget and will meet some basic indoor security needs, and you can deal with some attendant shortcomings, then this is a solid option.  Overall, this is a reluctant 3 stars.  It's o.k., but not bad enough that I would say that I don't like it.

Reviews.Title: Good camera set-up a nightmare.  Customer support required an hour on hold. No resolution.
Reviews.Author: Brad Walker
Reviews.Content: Just a bad experience all the way around.  I have clearwire and a Netgear router.  Evidently a bad combination.  Another friend bought one who's ISP is Comcast evidently not much better.  Avoid the frustration.

Reviews.Title: Great KittenKam..BUT
Reviews.Author: Jetpuffed
Reviews.Content: I bought this to keep an eye on my two new kittens while I am away from home.It was very easy to install on our home network; my son had it up and running in less than an hour.Getting the remote access wireless to work was another story.My son gave up and gave the task to my husband.My husband finally succeeded after much research.Apparently we have a Verizon router with some firewall issue...If you use Verizon, I recommend you Google "Foscam Verizon router setup".Picture quality is very good; night infrared vision is impressive; price of unit is great.Recommended if you know a nerd who can set up the remote wireless for you.

Reviews.Title: Pain to set up. No customer support
Reviews.Author: zee
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera after reading a number of reviews, both positive and negative. Decided to give it a shot.Setup was easy for the wired connection part of the setup but could not get it to work wirelesslesy. Tried foscam's website forum, googled extensively, used tips from other reviews on amazon. Could not get it to connect wirelessly.There is no customer support. The instructions in the manual say to contact the seller first ! This is absurd.When i called amazon, the representative was shocked to hear this.Amazon should not sell such a product where the manufacturer explicity says not to contact them !Returned product !

Reviews.Title: Foscam FI8910W
Reviews.Author: Hybred
Reviews.Content: The wireless setup was a bit difficult. The instructions in the product reviews on Amazon were helpful and got me through it in minutes.  The camera does have two way audio but if you have a Mac you will not be able to run the audio through your internet browser.  The camera's movements are quiet even when you are standing close to it. I tried a D-Link 942L but the wireless range did not compare to this Foscam.  I was able to connect wirelessly through three walls to my courtyard and the connection was steady. For the money, this is a great camera.

Reviews.Title: only worked for one day
Reviews.Author: Ivy
Reviews.Content: I am considering return or exchange it.Wasted a lot time try to make it work. only worked for one day, then wont connect to network,  even tried change the cable.In hope to make it work through the LAN, still not able to connect to network.  By the way, I did purchase a few static IP address.I got another brand ip wireless camera at the same time. works very good since day one(haven't got chance to set the audio yet.  and there is no instruction at all for this one. But I wont mind as long as it works or I could figure it out how to make it work.).I will try one more time see if it able to connect to internet.Only view locally is no use for me.

Reviews.Title: Don't believe the hype.
Reviews.Author: thomas mski
Reviews.Content: I most likely research purchases more than most people and when it came to security cameras, I read most of these 900 or reviews.I am also fairy tech savvy and tend to be the friend that most call when their printer or computer is acting up.That said, I have had nothing but issues with these cameras.For starters, set up is nothing short of torture. While these don't promise to be 'plug and play', you will loose some hair in the tinkering that is required to get these going.I have to admit, I called tech support after a few hours and a gentleman logged into my machine and figured out a problem (that happened to be a typo in their 'manual').He was fairly friendly and incredibly helpful. But he's gone, and the problems persist.And please don't blame my network foscam. This camera sits 10 FEET from a wirelsss router.Cameras 'disappear' on a regular basis. I  log in to either my computer or via a well reviewed app on my iphone and after a minute or so, the camera freezes, then crashes.Only recourse is to go home, unplug and reset. What's the point of a 'remote' camera if I have to go home and reset all the time?And forget about a tiny power blip. I'm talking so short that the clocks don't even reset on the microwave or TV- but these cameras go haywire.I can't remember the last time I logged in and saw something OTHER than the ceiling. NEVER is the camera pointing where it should be.Perhaps they work better when hardwired via ethernet cable. But I bought wireless cameras for a reason.Too late to return, but not too late to warn buyers. Unless you drive an MG or Triumph (which would suggest you enjoy consistently tinkering to get it to run well), STEER CLEAR OF THESE CAMERAS!

Reviews.Title: Very nice for the price
Reviews.Author: Richard Bitting "Geek Gadget Freak"
Reviews.Content: I got the two pack of these cameras. They were very simple to set up even using a Mac. It came with a program to scan for the camera's IP and then connect to configure them. At first the IE Active-X login wouldn't work. Then they came out with a firmware update. Once this was applied, the IE logon allowed the control to install and enabled many more features than just the "Push" Firefox type viewing. In addition, I found a great IOS program that runs on the Iphone and Ipad and allows me total control AND two way audio. The night vision works great too. At least up to about 10 feet or so. Only problem appears to be that moths can see the infrared and love to perform acrobatics to show off and it causes the motion detect to go off. But overall, for the price they are hard to beat (with the latest firmware). I love the ability to move in almost any direction too. It also allows FTP and Email notification of alarm conditions so I can instantly know when something is there. The only complaint I would have is that I can't set a motion detect zone or zones like my old D-Link camera could. I'd like to be able to just monitor a portion of the field of view for motion instead of the apparent averaging of overall frame motion, so I'm giving it 4 stars instead of 5, but still for the low cost, it's great.

Reviews.Title: Awesome IP Camera!
Reviews.Author: S. Barrett
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera so my wife and I could check up on our house.  Since I travel for work occasionally, it makes it easy for me to check in on our cat and make sure the house is OK.  The instruction were easy for me to follow, but I work in IT for a living.  I would imagine that your average consumer would have a bit of a hard time following the rather poorly translated instructions.  However, if you have a technically adept family member or friend, they could set it up pretty quickly for you.  Now I can easily open up the app (not included, but there are plenty of free ones in the App Store) and check on my house.

Reviews.Title: cant record to NAS
Reviews.Author: pjrey "pjrey"
Reviews.Content: just found this out... after spending 1.5 hours on hold to talk with the tech... unable to record to NAS (unless you have software/pc running 24/7) booo.. my sharx cam does this no prob.. thought for sure this unit would.. thought wrong...

Reviews.Title: Good Not Great
Reviews.Author: David Y
Reviews.Content: I own 3 Cams the D-Link 930L(my first cam), D-link 932L, and Foscam FI8910W. I have the D-link 932L at the front door, because it has Night Vision. The D-Link 930L facing my sliding back door it doesn't have Night Vision. I have the Foscam facing out the second floor window of my room overlooking my backyard. I like the Foscam it has a good picture but a little choppy compared to my 932L. The field of view of the Foscam seems wider compared to my 930L. I Like the Pan/Tilt, because it lets me scan my whole backyard where my 930L only lets me see part of my yard. The Night Vision on the Foscam doesn't work for me, because the Cam is a little fat, and sits far enough away from the window that it reflects the IR back blinding it. My 932L I can push up against the window allowing the IR to get through the glass, if you need a good front door cam with Night Vision I would recommend getting D-Link 932L. The Foscam was easy to setup only one small hic was that it changed the IP address by 3 numbers when I unplugged it to go wireless. No big deal, because the IP Camera Tool on the CD will show you the change. The Firmware was also the latest version, which was nice to see on an out of the box device. All in all if you need a good indoor cam this is a great cam to have. If you want to use it to monitor the outside of your house at night I wouldn't recommend it, unless you're going to mount it outside not sure how weather proof it is. The Night Vision thing was the only reason I dropped it one star. I use my iPad to monitor all my cams with an app called uCamPro HD, it cost $10 after you do the in app purchase for multi cams. It allows me to view all my cams live not just one live, and the rest still images like some apps do. With all my cams I feel like Tony Montana from Scarface. lol

Reviews.Title: Dont waste your money
Reviews.Author: Ray
Reviews.Content: The GOOD: daytime video is clear. Comes with ftp function for "video recording", the price.The Bad: if you set indoor facing out like behind a window its worthless, the infrared or nightvision leds causes a glare which reflects back into the video causing you to lose all visibility outside.Extremely fussy if you set motion sensor notification and ftp recording simultaneously. i set ftp recording every 3 seconds and motion sensor notification. what happens is if motion sensor is triggered an email is sent every two seconds (my setting) until motion stops i end up losing video segments of 10 seconds or greater.Likes to reboot, most changes require the cam to reboot and go back on center.software: this does not come with any live/streaming recording software.The Ugly.Power cable is not very long not a lot of flexibility for  positioning around windows with blinds as the base of device is bulky.IE compatibility is limited as IE does not play nice with the foscam activeX add-on ( to be fair this is the case with many cctv appliances).

Reviews.Title: Horrible camera!!!
Reviews.Author: Chris
