Reviews.Content: Our office got 3 of these camerass and within 6 months of use, all 3 failed on us one way or another. 1 unable to connect to the internet (can connect to wifi), 1 the image turned blurry with color distortion, and the last one it seems like the motor stops and can't pan (every time trying to pan the motor have a stuck sound). For those people who wrote positive reviews on this camera must be fake reviewers or they got bribed somehow by Foscam. There is no way on earth this camera can even earn this kind of positive reviews unless quality is not an issue to you.Going back to 6 months ago, I recalled how frustrated it was to set these cameras up. It took us nearly 3 hours with our IT department just to get 1 camera up and running. We were not planning to call Foscam because we do not want strangers to remote access our server computers. Plus, I don't think you can rate a product with 5 stars with "good technical support" because the best customer service should be NO CUSTOMER SERVICE, which means the product should simply just be easy to setup.Anyways, stay away from these horrible Chinese products with horrible English instruction manual, Foscam should stay on ebay because that's where they should belong!!Sorry on the harsh words because consumer should be warned. As for those who wonders what other better camera available out there, here are couple that I highly recommended since our office and I have both now:1. Cavalry IPC10010 Pan & Tilt High Resolution Indoor Wireless IP/Network Camera (Black) - Compatible with Android and iOS - This is by far the best one I recommend. Our office replace all of our cameras to this one. You can set this camera up in probably less than 5 minutes, picture quality is great, 2 way voice sounds good too, and great Wi-Fi range distance.2. Dropcam Pro Wi-Fi Wireless Video Monitoring Camera - I got this last year for my home due to a yahoo review and this camera is as good as the Cavalry in terms of image quality and ease of setup. However, this camera cost a lot more at $199 + monthly cloud service. I would probably buy the Cavalry if it was available earlier.By the way, based on other reviewers who wrote negative reviews on the Foscam either got called working for the competition or their reviews all turned into not helpful. It makes you wonder is Amazon reviews even legit anymore... Companies like Foscam should simply focus on improving their products instead of spending their time on writing fake reviews.Anyways, buy at your own risk.

Reviews.Title: Caught on Camera!
Reviews.Author: The General

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_moHPPWR2VI6QKQcurrentClick) { return cv_moHPPWR2VI6QKQcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 1:21 MinsI purchased this camera because I have a special needs child with Prader-Willi Syndrome. Prader-Willi is a genetic disorder - people with PWS have an insatiable appetite and cannot control themselves around food. If you came to our home you would find our all the food in our house under lock and key.My wife and I wanted to leave our 12 year old PWS child alone for a bit, but wanted the security of being able to watch the kitchen to make sure she did not eat (even with the food under lock and key). It was very easy to set up and configure. I already have a Synology NAS, so I connected the camera and set it up to record when it identified movement.Little did I know that this would also catch our 9 year old son trying to take the laptop up to his room after his bed time. As you can see from the video, I did not hide the camera and he knew right where it was located. He made a wise choice and only displayed a little bit of attitude.

Reviews.Title: Scary security issues. Not user friendly
Reviews.Author: C Bang
Reviews.Content: Played with it for an hour and already too many frightening security issues that are making me return it and avoid this entire brand.They require my name and email address to download a firmware update. Email with the firmware link never arrived. Now my email address is somewhere in a database they keep, and it's a pretty good guess that everyone in this database has a network camera. Seems like a fun target for hacking. Also the same model of camera can require different firmware depending on what it shipped with and they warn you that using the wrong firmware will "brick" it.The camera includes a dynamic DNS service, but this service forces you to use a domain that they've picked in seemingly numerical order. Mine was in the format [.....] and on the second try of guessing numbers I was able to locate another person's network. What's to stop someone from scanning these with a basic script and then running some dictionary attacks on those networks?Taking a snapshot on the web interface displays your username and password in the URL in plain text such as [....] . So now if my computer is compromised or accessed in any way, the attacker can simply check my browser history for my full login and password.Finally, I change the port number and accidentally type "70000" instead of "7000". Camera accepts it and reboots, but web browsers give me an error because the port number is too high. No idea how to access the camera at this point.Even if it still worked, there is no way I would keep this thing in my home. These are just the things I discovered by accident. Who knows what other security issues you could discover by actually looking.

Reviews.Title: Really bad product.
Reviews.Author: Thomas H.
Reviews.Content: There is a reason these cameras are inexpensive. Mine worked for two weeks. I bought two of them, got them working and thought I'd made a good purchase. Two weeks later, the screen went blank; then it wouldn't accept my password; then one of them would randomly come alive and scan the room (creepy). I sent them back. I had also purchased the Iris software because I was planning on expanding to several other cameras if these worked out. Thankfully, I never opened the box. Additionally, I purchased mounting brackets, which I didn't need because the cameras come with brackets. I regret not spending a little more for a better product. After reading way too many reviews, I'm going for the DropCam.

Reviews.Title: Lack of Tech Support
Reviews.Author: R.K.
Reviews.Content: I tried to follow the instructions, written in poor English. I then called tech support, and I'm still on hold as I write this review. A half an hour ago I was number 6. I rollup up to the number two caller, then constantly fall back down the hold list to number 5 or 6. This is very frustrating. THEIR TECH SUPPORT IS BOGUS BOGUS BOGUS !!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: PINK SCREEN OF DEATH
Reviews.Author: Darkcrawler
Reviews.Content: Bought this product last week, and tried to set it up immediately. Once everything was pulled in, the camera shows a pink screen. It flickers back and forth to what the camera is directed to but that flicker happens probably every 20 seconds. Played with the settings and rebooted the camera but no good. Called the Tech support, was waiting for 30 mins even though I'm number 2 on the waiting line. The IT guy just told me to reboot it, didn't work so he said it was defected. Not wasting my time with another one of these..

Reviews.Title: Some misleading reviews
Reviews.Author: Kevin Morrison
Reviews.Content: I've read a lot of the reviews for this product, and having owned it myself for over a month now, I felt compelled to say something, if only to debunk some of what is being discussed. The "most helpful critical reviewer" makes a very valid point, and if that problem is persisting then heed his advice, but it is one that many of the people who negatively reviewed this camera are not coming into contact with.I purchased this camera for home security purposes and as far as I am concerned it performs flawlessly. The live feed, motion detection, infrared functionality, silent alarm system (as well as the SMTP mail server functionality), free DDNS service, and FTP upload all work as intended. The main reason that I'm docking a single star for this device is because the setup can be excruciating; a reboot of the device is required following every major change made to its function, and if you're enabling all of the above settings like I did, you'll be rebooting this device many times during setup. The device is also slow to connect to a wireless network - the instructions suggest waiting up to a minute for it to connect properly before attempting to access it - but once this waiting period is over it responds rapidly and as it should.The main problem with this device seems to be the fact that its webUI is not very user friendly. This is true to some extent, but once you start meandering into the realm of do-it-yourself home security, some tech knowledge should be a given. Docking stars for an item too complicated for you to use seems somewhat foolish; the functionality still exists, but because the users here seem to be unable to delve into it they are saying it's a lousy product, which is untrue. This also applies for firmware upgrades. Yes you are required to upgrade two sets of firmware for this camera to get it to work as best it can, but this is no different than updating drivers on a computer hardware, or installing regular updates on a PC. As time goes by firmwares age and need to be replaced, this is a fact of the technology age we live in. I would be upset with a product that DIDN'T require you to update firmware out of the box, because this means, among other things, that they've likely stopped updating the firmware, and the functionality of the device is not being optimized.I have also read reviews that complain about the DDNS service offered to you through the device, claiming that they felt it was unsafe. Registering a DDNS is not unsafe in and of itself, primarily because knowing about the DDNS does not give somebody access to your home network any more than knowing your IP address does. This is also ironic, because the DDNS functionality is probably one of the easier things about this camera to configure, yet the people here having difficulty configuring the camera were upset about its inclusion. However, accessing this camera via the provided DDNS is not the only way to do so remotely, because as anybody who has registered a DDNS knows, it simply reroutes a customized web address to your IP address. I use another DDNS that I already had registered to access my cameras, and simply leave the one that came included with the camera deactivated. All of the remote functionality is exactly the same.I mean no offense to other reviewers, but I felt that my experience with the camera needed to be cataloged. If you are technology impaired, this might not be the camera for you as so many of these other reviews have experienced first hand. If, however, you are fully capable of managing your own home network and router via a webUI and understand the basics of port forwarding, I'm confident you'll be able to unravel the mystery that is the FOSCAM FI8910W, assuming their quality control issue has been reigned in (having not come across that issue myself, I can't comment on it here).

Reviews.Title: Poor video quality and unreliable connection
Reviews.Author: Romotive
Reviews.Content: The video quality is bad and the camera is constantly disconnecting from my network. The 640x480 image will only work for 1 second and then the image stops streaming in my browser. Audio only works for Windows IE. I would not recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Still selling old product.
Reviews.Author: Cindy
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera after reviewing all the reviews and responses from Foscam US. Foscam US states they have identified the issue and as of November 2013, all cameras sold from them or thru Amazon would have the new hardware. Since it is late January 2014 I figured I would be ok. The camera has a clearly marked sticker on the bottom that states it was manufactured in the 2nd month of 2013. The camera freezes as it sees fit and I am glad Amazon has a good return policy. I really want a camera but now I dont know how many I have to buy and return in order to "use up" their old inventory before I get one with the updated gear. Frustrating when you decide to support a company who admits they have a problem and have fixed it when they clearly haven't.

Reviews.Title: no wonder it was cheap
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Total Nut"
Reviews.Content: it gave me and is giving me a very hard time it keeps resetting on its own. this is not something you plug in and it works so if your not a tech get ready to become one, it took me six hours to setup.. doing the lan setup was easy getting the IP setup was a pain and you have to pay for a dyndns ip service thats about $25 a year. it comes with an instruction video that helps but if you dont know how to port forward or how to find your IP address get ready for long hours setting this up. I got it working on my cell phone and can see my camera anywhere, but if i pan around it will reset. it has a really nice see in the dark (IR) it also has a mic so you can hear and a speaker so you talk to anyone near camera I freaked out my dog LOL all in all its okay but not easy to setup

Reviews.Title: Vert frustrated!
Reviews.Author: deanna
Reviews.Content: We can't get it hooked up and every time we call foscam to help they tell us they can't get it to connect either. We don't know if it's the camera or not because as long as we are in our house we can view the camera but that defeats the point of having it... Very frustrating!

Reviews.Title: Camera OK, Software poor
Reviews.Author: Phasr "phasr"
Reviews.Content: The camera itself is fairly decent, but the firmware and UI are poorly written. In correspondence with Foscam, their tech people do not appear to have a rudimentary knowledge of this camera's software, and thus are unable to afford much, if any, assistance. I have corresponded by email and phone with these folks to no avail. I finally developed my own solution via a work-around, but unless you have a a solid background in hardware and software. you might be better off selecting another camera.

Reviews.Title: Difficult set-up
Reviews.Author: J Leach
Reviews.Content: The directions and video say different things on the set-up. I consider myself pretty computer-savy, but the directions were confusing. After spending a few hours trying to set it up, I called Foscam. I had a difficult time the first 2 times I called (was on hold for 30 minutes, then they hung up on me). The 3rd time I called, someone was able to set up the wireless remotely but his directions were different than what was listed in the booklet.  However, the 8090 port was blocked on my internet. I called my internet service and was not able to get the port opened. I spent several more hours browsing the internet to try and unblock this port without success. I finally gave up and am returning the camera. The set-up should not require this much time and effort.

Reviews.Title: Piece of Crap With No Real Technical Support!
Reviews.Author: M. Brown "Brownie"
Reviews.Content: I have used two other network cameras from 2 other companies. Both are much clearer to view and much easier to use. I called tech support for assistance. I was told 22 minute wait time and number 15 in line. When it got down to one minute and 3rd in line it began to reverse until I was told 3rd in line with a 25 MINUTE WAIT TIME!!!I called from another phone and THE EXACT SAME THING HAPPENED!!!I am not kidding! I don't believe they even have a tech support!I am returning it and going with one of the other 2 network camera companies I currently use.Beware!

Reviews.Title: Good Camera, Unstable Connection
Reviews.Author: Kinesus Beats
Reviews.Content: Camera quality is great. Night Vision works excellent.Setup is a bit tricky but simple and quick.I had to return this product because it keeps disconnecting, freezing or restarting.The app will always try to reconnect with this camera, it never stays on, when making any changes through the app, the camera would freeze.Sometime when trying to connect to the camera via IP address webpage, it won't connect unless you turn on/off the camera.Because this camera has some connection issue, I don't trust it can be a reliable camera to keep.

Reviews.Title: Camera worked great for a 2 months
Reviews.Author: E. Cunningham "Mr C"
Reviews.Content: Bought the camera in November.  Worked fine.  Then about 2 weeks ago, started rebooting every now and then.  Now reboots constantly.  Camera has become useless.  I did some internet searches and it appears to be a common problem with several Foscam models.  There are comments about power surges, but it is on a surge protector.I have several other cameras of different vendors.  This is my first foscam, i bought it for the price compared to the features.  It appears you get what you pay for here.

Reviews.Title: Non working product and pathetic customer service
Reviews.Author: Preeti Chaudhary
Reviews.Content: We were gifted this product when our baby was born. When we tried to use it through our laptop, the camera light suddenly went blank. I tried to reach out to the replacement department but they asked me to pay the 10 $ shipping fee for sending the product back. When I refused to pay for it, the replacement department went unresponsive. I am very much dissappointed with Foscam. Would go for another brand instead.

Reviews.Title: Wouldn't reccomend
Reviews.Author: dawn crowley
Reviews.Content: This was easy to set up but kept losing connectivity and then the power cable input stopped working within two weeks of opening it.  If I plugged it in and the cable hung down it turned off.  Eventually it stopped powering up all together.  I did not try a using another so I could say if this is an isolated incident or not.

Reviews.Title: Lousy customer service
Reviews.Author: Pamela M Powers
Reviews.Content: Have tried the chat line numerous times in an attempt to resolve the subnet doesn't match problem. Only once did I receive any suggestion. I followed that suggestion which did not work and then the chat timed out. Every other time the chat timed out without any reply from foscam. If you think you may need help don't buy this.

Reviews.Title: IP Camera
Reviews.Author: Ken Nakano
Reviews.Content: Works fine at first but loses video connection.  I have a few of these and would not recommend this version.I have reset it and tried many different things to get the video feed working again but to no avail.

Reviews.Title: troubles
Reviews.Author: niw330
Reviews.Content: i was on vacation a while back it quit working have had no pictures from it for months- do not know why???

Reviews.Title: An OK item - it does work
Reviews.Author: willb2
Reviews.Content: Be prepared for a lot of "hocus pocus", downloading this and that, AND it's best to have a knowledgeable friend or two around.  I only have 20yrs of computer use but not much in this realm.  A local telephone computer company's networking expert was able to make it work.  He was enthusiastic about the item initially but not so after struggling with it for a day or two.Yes, I telephoned (30min or more on hold) and emailed Foscam for assistance but none was offered.Good luck!

Reviews.Title: Disappointed
Reviews.Author: Yi Yuan
Reviews.Content: I have been using this camera for a month. Feel like it is more for fun or casual use. I can't really count it as a security camera.Things I like:1) Does what a very basic security camera does, including remote access, motion trigger, email/ftp upload;2) CheapThings I dislike:1) ~20% of the time, it generates unreadable jpeg.2) Not very reliable motion alarm. I set the sensitivity pretty high, but still it loses some frames during the motion (by loses I mean the captured images are supposed to be emailed or uploaded)3) The image quality/resolution is too low (I know this is not specific for this camera), it only captures 640x480, You can't really use a 640x480 image to tell anything. Today even the cheapest phone takes better picture than that;4) Some settings are not preserved after reboot. Each time after reboot, I have to manually re-adjust its angle, lights etc.Overall, if you are looking for a security camera, move on, look for something better.UPDATE: after a few more weeks of using, I decided to further downgrade it to 1 star.

Reviews.Title: Software doesn't load on Windows 8.1 64 bit machines
Reviews.Author: cjninct
Reviews.Content: Can't speak for other versions of Windows but I could not get the FOSCAM software that came with the camera to work.  Tried contacting Foscam customer service via live chat.  After entering my issue they never responded.

Reviews.Title: Buyer Beware - Buy another product instead
Reviews.Author: ChrisO
Reviews.Content: BIG BIG BIG. FOSCAM claims that they have a DNS server built into this cam. What they don't tell you is that it does not actually activate till 2016. What kind of weirdness is that? Tenvis has a a built in DNS that works out of the box when you port-forward. Which you have to do for any IP Cam you wish to access outside of your home for those that don't know what a port-forward is.To be sure I was getting the better device I order 2 of this Foscam Wireless Cams Foscam FI8910W Pan & Tilt IP/Network Camera with Two-Way Audio and 1 TENVIS JPT3815W Wireless IP Pan/Tilt/ Night Vision Internet Surveillance Camera Built-in Microphone With Phone remote monitoring as well. I can tell you from real-world experience, you want to go with the Tenvis one.Yes the manual looks better on the Foscam but my God it is a lot easier to setup the Tenvis than this Foscam. I bought these to place outdoors in a Foscam outdoor dome and I could barely connect to either FOSCAM cams. Tenvis connects all the time, changing or setting up WIFI on the Tenvis in the advanced view is "Simple Stupid" if you have a laptop or phone and you have connected to wifi you will know what to do it with the Tenvis. It's is called an IP CAM for a reason. Most people buying want the option to view these cams remotely or at the very least set them up on their WIFI network with ease.The Tenvis has a better UI - User Interface for actually viewing the cam than the FOSCAM, once again simple stupid. People that buy loads of IP Cams do not need bloatware or GIGs of software just to access their cam FOSCAM ships a big CD with loads of software but that does not justify the price and the crappy device.Initialization: When you send power to a device and the time it takes that device to power-up and be ready for action. FOSCAM slow, one of the 2 FOSCAM cams I got took sometimes over 5 mins just to get discovered on the network after it's rotationsAs far as specs go. They are identical in terms of features Tenvis more so with the actual working DNS server that lets you view your cam from outside your network without paying for a third-party DNS.I am ending this review with this, I am actually returning both FOSCAM cams and getting 4 Tenvis cameras for my house. At $20 cheaper per unit as well.I hope my review helps whoever reading make the right decision on these FOSCAM cams. They are pretty crappy compared to their competition.Cheers...

Reviews.Title: Great "baby monitors"
Reviews.Author: Matthew
Reviews.Content: We initially got one when we put our toddler in his big boy bed so we could watch what he was doing. Since then, we have added one in the nursery as a baby monitory, and in the rec room in the basement so that we can keep an eye on the kids as they play. I may also get more to use them as home-security.  In the daylight, the video quality and colors are pretty good. Definitely sufficient for my needs. At night (with the IR LEDs), everything looks black and white, but it is still sufficient for my needs.  The two-way audio is great since I can politely ask (aka yell at) my kids to behave.  I am a tech-head, so for me they were very easy to set up; but I can see how it could be difficult (just Google it for some good instructions).  I use LiveCams Pro on iPhone and iPad; but there are several options for clients.  I also set up remote access via a VPN connection (remember, tech-head).  I currently don't use them to record or save photos when motion is sensed; but I like that they can do that if I choose to use them for security.

Reviews.Title: Waste of Time
Reviews.Author: Jeff Westsmith
Reviews.Content: This product is incredibly unreliable.  When it functions properly it does everything as advertised but unfortunately seems to have a glitch every few weeks prompting another (or multiple) time consuming call(s) to Foscam.  I've tried to be patient for 6 months now, but the latest crash is the last straw.  At this point, $99/year for dropcam cloud storage is a small price compared to the hours of wasted time spent troubleshooting.  Do not buy this camera, it is a giant time suck and one of the most aggravating piece of electronics I have ever owned.As a side note, at the end of a number of troubleshooting sessions, Foscam tech support have insisted that I login to Amazon.com and leave a positive review which leads me to be skeptical of the high number of 5 star reviews.

Reviews.Title: Baby Camera
Reviews.Author: Ryan D. Griffin
Reviews.Content: First off, this setup is a bit challenging (you've been warned).  Unless you have some experience with port forwarding on your wireless router, then this might be a bit challenging to have setup so that you can remote view when away from the home. Once this is up and running, it's fantastic.  The app was only $5 in the store and works flawlessly through all of our devices (multiple iPhones (4, 5, etc) and iPads (mini and gen 2). With the latest round of updates, Foscam seems to have fixed most of the issues that we experienced early on and the background noise has been much reduced which helps when you leave this on through the night.  We've now got two of these cameras setup (due to the price, we could now afford multiples) and it's very comforting to be able to check in on the nanny throughout the day.

Reviews.Title: Ok but not great.
Reviews.Author: Tony Turner
Reviews.Content: Setup Is difficult. They spent more on the quality of the camera than the quality of the software with it. It does not work out of the box remotely on my Uverse router.

Reviews.Title: Kitty Cam on my iMac, iPhone, iPad
Reviews.Author: Pat
Reviews.Content: I read so many ratings for both this camera and dozens of others.  I read all the flak about Foscam employees inflating the ratings.  I had purchased another brand previously and had to return it because it wouldn't work at all with my MAC equipment.  I decided to risk buying this camera since I didn't want to spend $500 for a unit.  I am very pleased with this unit and I would recommend it to anyone.The caveats.  Yes, it does take some know how in order to get all the functions working, but the instructions are quite clear.  We travel a lot and I wanted to be able to terrorize my cats while we were gone! :-)  Just kidding, but my wife does like the idea of keeping track of them.To me this is a quality unit and the still images and streaming video both are good quality, both when there is light in the room and with infrared.  I connected it with Ethernet cable and then wirelessly and it works great.  I can move it anywhere there is an electric source and it is within range of my wireless connection.  I chose to use NO-IP.com for free dynamic connection.  When I am sitting at the hospital I can bring up my address on my iPhone5 and see if the cats are getting into trouble - their norm.The motion detection works well and it is cool that I can also forward shots to an email address.  The two way audio allows me to "talk" (actually my wife, I'm a dog person) to the cats and watch them look all over the place to see where I am hiding.  Heh in my old age it doesn't take much to amuse me.I may buy two more of these to put in other locations, one outside.  So it doesn't matter to me if the claims that Foscam employers are inflating the ratings, I found out for myself what the unit is all about.  I have only had it for a couple weeks so I can't comment on longevity yet.

Reviews.Title: The old ones were good, but the new ones STINK
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Staff"
Reviews.Content: I needed a camera to setup for a friend in another town.  I already have three Foscam FI8910W that were great, so it seemed a "no-brainer" to buy another.  Well the video is terrible at 640x480, even in broad daylight.  For example, an image of a pegboard with tools from 7 feet is so bad that you could not recognize any single tool.  I wished I'd checked this earlier so there would be time for an exchange, but I didn't.The instructions warn that there are "counterfeits".  The instructions say a real FI8910W has 3 labels on the bottom of the base.  We checked, there were 3 labels, so I guess this is the real thing.I guess it's the latest sign of desperation among manufacturers.  They will soil their reputation for a few bucks.  I think they put out a few good cameras to get the reviews, then produce much more junk to rip off anyone who trusts them.  I'll never buy Foscam again.

Reviews.Title: Wireless will NOT connect.
Reviews.Author: David Tompkins
Reviews.Content: Purchased for wireless set up, but the camera will NOT connect to the router via wifi.  It is very disappointing, and the port forwarding is way to complicated.  I am greatly disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Poor product
Reviews.Author: Henry V. Nhan "Wireless expert"
Reviews.Content: Do not buy this item, The tech support waiting too long time about 45 minute, and this item when use with wireless not connect well and poor signal.

Reviews.Title: Great for Baby Monitor
Reviews.Author: Jen F. "educator and mom"
Reviews.Content: After buying the Motorola Blink1 Wi-Fi Video Camera for Remote Viewing with iPhone and Android Smartphones and Tablets from my local baby store, I was dissatisfied.  More accurately, my computer engineer husband was dissatisfied.  It required that you use their website and go through their network and the thing was really expensive.  So, after doing some research we purchased the Foscam.  We are very pleased with this purchace!  It is a third of the price of the other camera, you can put it on your own home network and download the app you wish to use on your phone or tablet.  The only features this camera is lacking from the other is the ability to play lullabies and tell me the temp in the baby's room, these are things I don't really care about anyway.  I love that this camera pans and tilts and has infrared.  I can even see my baby breathing at night, his chest rising and falling, the picture quality is so great!

Reviews.Title: No luck with wireless
Reviews.Author: RN_Owasso
Reviews.Content: Works fine with ethernet.  Won't connect at all to a network with any security.  Turn security off, and this camera improves to intermittent connectivity.  Many others with the same issue - wish I'd seen that earlier.  And to top it off, no returns.  Thanks Foscam.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera, Painstaking Installation, Pathetic iPhone App
Reviews.Author: Dan Huse
Reviews.Content: Given the mostly positive reviews on Amazon, I wasn't expecting the ordeal that I went through to set up this camera.  Like most people who buy a wifi IP cam, my intent was to connect it to my home network via our wifi network.  We wanted to use it in our twin daughters' room as a video baby monitor.First, because the product description did not mention that it came with a wall mount, I bought one that I did not need.  The one that comes standard with this camera is quite nice with adjustable angle to your preference, depending upon how high you end up mounting it on the wall.  Hence, I will have to go through the hassle of returning the one that I purchased separately.  I wish the product description had mentioned the wall mount.After I installed the camera on the wall and got it plugged in, I thought the biggest challenges were behind me.  Surely, setting up a wifi camera would be simple, or so I thought.  I opened up the "Quick Start" manual, which turned out to be a big lie, and the beginning of probably a 90-minute ordeal.  The application that it told me to start on my computer opened to a blank screen--not a darn thing to tell me anything that I had done right, wrong, or indifferent.  After lots of head scratching and online research, I came to the conclusion that it must be showing a blank screen because the application was not finding a webcam connected to the network.  How could this be?  I have a wifi network that works great for everything else.  I then determined, after much painful laboring through a poorly written "Quick Start" manual and Foscam website that in order to set the camera up on wifi, one must first set it up as a wired connection, and then configure it for wifi.  This was utter nonsense to me.  If a person wanted to operate a camera on wifi, then WHY would he first have to connect it wired?!?  This would be like buying a car, only to find out that you have to push it home before you can drive it.  I was dumbfounded.  Then, after more laboring through the "Quick Start" manual and more web searching, I found out about a feature that many routers have called WPS, which allows for easy connection of wifi devices without having to go through the painful online setup.  After getting into my router control panel on my computer (with no help from Foscam, of course), I was able to turn this feature on and get my router to connect to the camera automatically.  Thank heavens, as connecting my camera via hardwire in able to eventually get to wifi would have probably led to me returning this camera.Once connected to the network, getting it working should have been a snap.  Wrong again!  It was far from intuitive, and the manual was of little help to me.  Eventually, though, I got it working.Now the fun part, I thought.  I got to set up the iPhone app, which is how I really intended to use this camera--as a video baby monitor.  I followed the instructions to find the app that had the icon like the one they showed in the manual.  Great, I thought.  I was rated only 2 stars by users.  That should have been my first clue.  The app was incredibly cryptic to understand and set up.  When I finally got it working, I discovered that it offered NO AUDIO FEED, even though the camera does have 2-way audio.  Incredible miss!  So, I had it in me to look for a better app that would work with the camera.  I did find an outstanding app that supports this model of Foscam and also offers 2-way audio capability, such that you can listen AND talk.  Yes, you can talk into your phone, and it will transmit the audio to the camera wherever you have it located.  Very cool.  The name of the app that I purchased from the App Store is LiveCams Pro, and it was $3.99, a small price to pay to make this camera work the way it was supposed to work in the first place.As I have it configured, we must be on our wifi network in order to use the iPhone app.  There is a way to set it up to work on 3G coverage, if you are outside your wifi range, but there were 3 reasons I did not go through the ordeal to configure this.  First, it was complicated and difficult, as I read through it.  Second, I have a secured wifi network, and I like the idea of people needing access to our network before they can view the video feed of my girls in their room.  Third, since we are using this as a video baby monitor, we will always be home and connected to wifi when using it.  There is really no practical reason that we would ever need to connect via 3G.  Do know, however, that you can configure it that way if you so desire.Importantly, I have to say that the camera itself is impressive.  It pans silently, has good audio pickup (for listening), and transmits audio from out iPhones to the camera (when we speak into our iPhones) clearly.  The infrared lights work amazingly well in pitch darkness to make everything perfectly visible.  When you turn on the lights, a light sensor turns off the infrared lights, and you are left with great full-color video feed.In the end, we are happy with this product, but the road from purchase to full operation was painful.  Hopefully this review will help you out, if you endeavor to purchase one yourself.

Reviews.Title: Very difficult to Connect
Reviews.Author: Ashley Cline
Reviews.Content: I had to return this camera after trying for over an hour to connect to my wireless network. I was able to use the camera fine when it was hardwired to my router but I wasn't able to ever get it to work on my wireless network. I like to think of myself as pretty good with computers but this was way beyond my skill level.

Reviews.Title: Wi-fi inop.
Reviews.Author: inspain92
Reviews.Content: This camera works really well - if the CAT-5 LAN cable is plugged in.  I was unable to get the wi-fi function to work, and I know a thing or two about networks.  I would have rated it higher but for the wi-fi issue.  As I said before, the camera works great when plugged in.  This is not a bad product at all, but mine didn't work as advertised.

Reviews.Title: Preliminary review
Reviews.Author: G. Robinson "Extensive reader"
Reviews.Content: I have just got this setup so this is preliminary.The Good:Good quality video at standard def; not the surveillance video crap.Good controls especially for the money.If you go to the Foscam us / tools-support site there are a bunch of useful videos on setup. Don't bother with the CD just download the latest software.The video setup instructions could be better, they are complete but not well done in places and a little tedious.  However; a big improvement over the written instructions.Excellent pan and tilt range.Nice long DC cord for power.Includes a flexible mounting bracket.Easy to put together and in service.DHCP is now off by default.If you know the camera name or IP you can just use that in the browser to get to the camera and not mes with the IP camera tool.[update]Works fine with my Kindle in 'phone mode so should work with any Android device.[\update]The Bad:Needs DC, there is no battery option. There are battery to AC converters but they cost more than the Foscam.Takes up bandwidth on your 2.4GHz network--apparently will not work on the 5GHz band.No way to program a scan. e.g. start at the bottom of the stairs scan up then scan horizontally down a hall or even just limit the scan travel. (A little unfair given the price price point.)Need to get the camera running to determine the driver to use.The Ugly:No zoom (again given the price point not really expected.)Plastic mounting bracket appears frigale.To avoid power cord problems and eliminate the drain on WiFI bandwidth you can run Power over Ethernet cable to the camera. You need to run one line in any case.[update]The SW supplied with the camera is limited and you need something like the Blue Iris Professional - Supports Many IP Camera Brands Including Foscam and Agasio, Zone Motion Detection, H.264 Compression Recording, E-mail And SMS Text Messaging Alerts! software to get all the features you would like to have.Audio on non-IE browsers requires a obscure plug with limited compatibility.As the camera gains up (IR mode) the screen blinks and gets grainier.IR limited to ~100m to see something is there and ~50M to see what.Outside in bright sun you can see a large object (garbage truck) as recognizable at ~200M, and that something is there at 1000M.  But while you can see a person at ~60M there is no ability to recognizable faces beyond ~10M.[\update]So far I haven't done any distance tests nor tried remote viewing on a 'phone. I'm strictly using the camera for remote surveillance when I am home. (Critter problems.)I will update after more experience and testing.

Reviews.Title: Great Baby Camera
Reviews.Author: Macygrey09
Reviews.Content: We use this camera as a baby monitor, not as a home security system.Pros:Very clear back and white picture as well as colorNight vision works wellCan talk through cameraCons:Doesn't turn a full 360 degrees or all the way downIt has to be plugged into the network instead if being wireless. Which causes it to be a hassle to move. But I like to be able to see my baby breathing so it's worth the extra hassle.If you can wire this device I would highly recommend as a baby camera. If your going to use it wirelessly, I'd get something else.

Reviews.Title: Terrible Technical Support
Reviews.Author: Amy Wainio
Reviews.Content: I purchased it, set it up, it was working fine, but needed help on remote access.  While on hold for over 48 minutes camera stopped working, was on call for 5 minutes the got disconnected.  Had already given control to PC so they could trouble shoot so we intiated a chat and that continued for about 35 minutes and the he stopped responding.  Having sent me a response intended for someone else on one occasion.  Very Disappointed am returning.

Reviews.Title: Foscam 8910 IP camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Worked in the beginning just fine but the Email Alert quit.  Contacted FOSCAM, checked their forum for support to NO avail.  As though they are in the business of selling and not supporting their product. I'm tire of waiting for an update or reason for this major disconnect! If these cameras DO NOT forward Email Alerts they are merely nice looking camera(s) that tilts and pans.  Just when I was ready to buy even more cameras this happens and 'it continues'.  Buyer beware!UPDATE-----After purchasing BlueIris software the camera(s) perform fine.  Only issue I still have is I want HD now:^)  ***They do the job as intended but thanks to the software package they are finally working with live streaming and Emailing of JPG and MP4 videos identifying date/time stamps.  Would like to afford about a dozen more.  I just had to correct my previous rating.

Reviews.Title: Works great as a baby monitor
Reviews.Author: angela
Reviews.Content: Instead of getting a baby video monitor, we invested in Foscam's IP Camera.  It functions just like a video monitor in that it has night vision, two-way communication, and you have the peace of mind of being able to see your baby rather than just hear him.  But the differences are what sold us - instead of having a device you have to use to watch your baby, it works via a private IP address, so you view the screen from your computer, tablet, phone, etc.  And, because it isn't labeled with the word "baby," it is less expensive than an actual baby monitor, but with better technology behind it.  This is one of my "must have for baby" products - I have a full list posted at [...]

Reviews.Title: Good, but a few things you need to know up front
Reviews.Author: T. Howlin "bookie monster"
Reviews.Content: Rather than some long winded review, how about the pros and cons:PROS:InexpensiveDecent quality pictureWireless setup for your LAN is a breezeWell builtEasy to controlCONS:Remote viewing setup is a chore - read up on port forwarding before you installIf you have a dynamic IP (almost all ISP's assign IP addresses dynamically), you will lose your remote viewing if your ISP resets your IP or you lose you modem like during a power outage.  To prevent this, you have to go through a somewhat complicated process of singing up with a (free) DNS service like no-ip.biz.  then you have to configure the camera to work with that service.  I'm neither and expert nor an idiot and it took me a full day to get everything right.The IR function is fair at best - you won't get any worthwhile detail in near darkness.The camera runs all the time but only captures video during an alarm but you need an FTP server to upload the actual video so while you can watch it real time on your portable device you won't be capturing the full video, only snapshots.The alarm function requires going into the software to deactivate unless you want hundreds of photos being emailed constantly of your dog wandering around the house.  There really should be a desktop icon for the alarm function to quickly turn on/off.Cord on the AC adapter is way too short to mount the camera up high on the wall where it is less noticeable to potential thieves.Conclusion:  It's an excellent deal for <$100 considering not too many years ago a camera of this capability and quality would have cost many multiples of its current price.  Just recognize its limitations and you'll be pleased.

Reviews.Title: Nice feature set, but picture is lacking.
Reviews.Author: Michael A. Silver
Reviews.Content: This is one of those products that are hard to review.  It doesn't claim to be a high resolution camera, and it isn't, so can I ding the product a star for having such a poor quality picture?  The picture quality is pretty bad.  Once there is distance from the lens, you may have trouble recognizing faces.  Whether or not this camera is for you, depends on your needs.  To use as a general web cam, it's really great.  For  surveillance, it's a bit lacking.Here is a brief list of the pros and cons:Pros:* Decent built in software, able to access via a browser, phone, tablet, etc (although it's not sized for a smaller screen)* Works with a lot of Android apps and open source ones for the PC* Respectable price* Remote Pan and Tilt, 2 way audio, infrared "lights"* Motion alerts (FTP and email)* Viewing over the internet* Can setup users to control who has access to camera* Video feed* Wifi or ethernet* Lot's of other smaller but interesting options in the softwareCons:* Poor picture quality.  Very grainy, with or without infrared.  Unless you know the person in the image, you may have trouble identifying them.* Any motion occurring during the picture will be blurred* Motion alerts go off all the time due to sunlight in the windows* Video can't be sent via alerts* Video is slow, perhaps 10 frames per sec.I bought an open box version and it's probably worth the cost at that price.  If I get another camera, I may spring for an HD version, perhaps with zoom.UPDATE: 12/20/2013I've been using the camera a lot and the primary reason I bought it was for the alerts.  The alerts are broken and broken badly.  They simply do not work.  On the lowest sensitivity, in 2 days, the camera sent 19,000 images to me.  Only about 200 were valid alerts.  I can't filter 19,000 images manually.  Also my email can't handle that many images, it gets overwhelmed.  I can't send them to an FTP server, since it bogs down with that many files.  I'm left with a camera that is mostly useless.My next venture will be to build a customer camera using a Raspberry Pie.

Reviews.Title: Excellent product!
Reviews.Author: Micah Klatt
Reviews.Content: Easy to set up.  Easy to use.  Easy to access from my computer or my android phone.We're using for our nursery to keep an eye on our little one.  However, she's still young enough that she doesn't spend much time in there yet.  But I've tried out the camera a little anyway.  I love that you can operate the movement of the camera remotely, through the computer or phone even.  I haven't really tried the sound features yet.As to setting it up remotely, I had it working without calling customer service, but it hasn't been completely consistent for some reason.  Not worried about it though.  I'm sure we'll get the kinks worked out.Also, just to make sure it's clear, the resolution is not that great.  It's good enough for monitoring, good enough for snapping some shots, but certainly not HD (which the product doesn't claim to be - just being clear).

Reviews.Title: A pretty good baby monitor.
Reviews.Author: K. Call
Reviews.Content: This is an awesome camera after you go through the hassle of setting it up. I use it as a baby monitor in conjunction with the iPhone app "foscam pro". My wife has an android and can't seem to find a good app for the camera.As for the features...The camera is feature rich with pan/tilt/motion detection/wireless/web/IR night vision, and more. I only wish the camera had optical zoom, but what can you expect at this price point? For the money, this is a great camera. When my little one outgrows the need for a monitor, I'll mount it near my front door for security.

Reviews.Title: No way
Reviews.Author: abey
Reviews.Content: Software is pretty buggy - was shipped with 11.37.2.49.  We used chrome to monitor, video froze after one day.Hardware looked promising and feature rich. However software, especially wireless connectivity was very buggy (chrome monitoring froze, moving camera caused device to reboot). Returning it after 2 days of troubleshooting. We happened to be a hands on networking specialist.  This is not worth your time.  Need to hire a new PM and a few good QA engineers FosCam!

Reviews.Title: Ok product for the price
Reviews.Author: Hernan
Reviews.Content: Don't buy it if you are not a geek. The UI is not very simple to use. Sound and MIC are not plug and play. It took me some time to make it work well, specially the router configuration.

Reviews.Title: Quality Control seems to be an issue with Foscam
Reviews.Author: Marcelo Fartura
Reviews.Content: I loved the product - It's full of cool features that really work and for the price it's a great deal.I'm giving it 2 stars right now because I bought 3 of these cameras and in less than a week I returned 2 that went down with different symptoms: One of them died completely and the other entered in a cyclic start up mode - It just never ended starting up, as soon as the startup procedure ended the camera started it all over resetting itself.Their customer service seems to be good - It did not take me long to talk to a human in the other side :)  But I really did not spend much time with them since I was not going to rely on those cameras even if they could guide on how to fix them by resetting to manufactory defaults or something like this.  I just returned them and Amazon, as usual, was great and shipped me replacements overnight!  Thank you once again Amazon!  Your customer service is by far the best I have ever had the opportunity to deal with.I have a friend who has 2 of these cameras too and he never had any issue so I might have been out of luck here - I will give it sometime and will correct this review in case the new ones don't die too.

Reviews.Title: Quality Control Problems?
Reviews.Author: R. B. Nerf
Reviews.Content: Several months ago I purchased a Foscam FI8910W and was quite satisfied with its performance.  On the strength of that, I recently purchased a 3 pack, that also came with the (surprisingly large) 9 dB antennas.  The new cameras (using either antenna) would not work in network conditions that the old camera found acceptable.  To make a long debugging story short, I put one of the new cameras adjacent to the old camera and called Foscam support.  They did a reasonable job of remote debugging, including copying the setup parameters from the working camera to the new camera, but had to admit defeat.  (Both of my tech support calls were promptly handled by competent personnel, but were problematic for connection quality: background noise in one case, combined with pronounced Indian accent in another.)  My opinion is that this batch of FI8910W's had some manufacturing defect. Interestingly, when packing to return the cameras, I found my old camera's box was a millimeter or so larger than the new ones.For the geeks among you, the problem was associated with network bandwidth, but not in a simple way.  The new cameras worked OK when deep inside the house, but would fail when put on a windowsill.  It was not simply signal strength, since my Airport Utility would be reporting "Excellent" signal strength for the connection to the camera.  I even purchased an Airport Express device to extend the network, and, while within a few feet of that device, the camera would work OK away from the window yet fail when on the sill.  To explain what I mean by "failure", if after a reboot of the camera, it was put in a lateral pan mode from the web browser interface, it would cease showing video before it had completed the lateral scan, and would subsequently reboot itself.  These symptoms were not as prominent if the camera was put in QVGA mode (320x240) or the low-light IR exposure mode was in force. The old camera would work OK in all these conditions.

Reviews.Title: Useless
Reviews.Author: Bensmoke
Reviews.Content: I spent several fustrating hours with this camera before returning it.  The software that it comes with is useless and looks cartoonish.  The camera occasionally connected and then loss connection again.

Reviews.Title: Don't Buy if you Want Wirelss
Reviews.Author: Roberto
Reviews.Content: First the good:  This is a very nice looking, well designed camera that is very quiet in operation.  While it would be nice to have a little higher resolution, the image is quite good.  The infrared works impressively well in total darkness and has a good range.  No problems at all connecting with ethernet cable.  If you don't need wireless and want to only use an ethernet cable, for the price this would be a four-star.Now the bad:  I returned it.  I am computer saavy and despite spending about three hours trying to get it to recognize/connect with  my Airport Extreme I could not, even after following the outstanding step-by-step instructions at this website (while it is for a slightly different model should have worked for this camera):[...]This website is essential, because the manual is useless.  However, despite how well written the website instructions are, I repeated them three times, and again could not connect.  Even if it had worked, the setup is so cumbersome, detailed, and so full of pitfalls that it is frustrating and time-consuming.  Also, you have to be extremely comfortable changing IP addresses, gateway addresses, subnet masks, etc. to even attempt setting this camera up for wireless. I didn't even attempt to learn more advanced setups that are theoretically possible for this camera.  The overall software is so-so.Related to the above, as mentioned the manual is awful: lacking detail, poorly written and poorly translated and of little help.  Whoever wrote the above website instructions should be hired by Foscam.  There has just got to be a simpler, more straightforward way to hook this up to wireless.

Reviews.Title: Don't waste your time
Reviews.Author: Lindsey Ellison
Reviews.Content: This camera is impossible to set up, and tech support is non-existent. We will be returning it promptly. Too bad about the fake five star reviews!

Reviews.Title: Nice IP Cam for the money, but you'll need DVR software to record
Reviews.Author: Robert Osorio
Reviews.Content: Nice camera. VERY good in low light except that the relay for the IR lights makes an annoyingly loud CLICK when it turns on or off, so around dusk I'll hear the camera click several times. Don't understand why this isn't a solid state switch instead of a relay.No DVR software comes with it, although they will sell you one from their website. HOWEVER instead I downloaded a free open source DVR app called iSpy Connect which was recommended in another review here.iSpy Connect was a little finicky to setup with the FOSCAM camera. If you use the default settings that the iSpy Connect wizard sets up for you, the framerate is horrible (less than 1 FPS). After digging through the forums what I found was that you need to use the optional VLC plugin as the video source (I think you need to have VLC installed, and I already had it installed as it's my primary media player app). Using the VLC plugin I'm now getting an average of 15 - 20 FPS. All I did was copy the URL from the FFMPG source tab and pasted it into VLC plugin tab as the source URL.iSpy Connect has the ability to record based on sound levels or motion detection. It's quite sophisticated.

Reviews.Title: Product was DOA
Reviews.Author: Sean
Reviews.Content: I was excited to get my camera set up but it wouldn't even be recognized by my router. I tried another router and it never showed up in my DHCP clients list.

Reviews.Title: No 2 way audio, no Mac Audio, no Mac support
Reviews.Author: John
Reviews.Content: The listening audio is fine, greatly improved over the 18918w. But there is STILL no usable audio via the camera speaker.Still no audio for Mac users at all, VLC is unreliable and buggy and not an option. There is no VLC plug in for Mac, so STILL no Mac audio.The ONLY browser that this thing works with audio wise is Netscape, so if you have a time machine or don't use a Mac, or don't need audio, the game is a 3 instead of a 1.

Reviews.Title: previous cameras worked fine - this one, not so much
Reviews.Author: Matthew S.
Reviews.Content: I've used many Foscams in the past without ANY problems on the same network setup(s) that these new cameras have problems with. The NEW firmware/UI on the 8910, or the camera itself, does NOT work in an Apple Airport Extreme environment. Camera will operate for a few minutes, then quickly drop it's wifi connection - requiring a complete restart (unplugging power) before it does the same, quick, crash. On and on. Already lost hours trying to patiently get them to work as older versions did without any hassle. Bottom line, don't buy this camera. Hopefully Foscam will hear about the issues and update the software in the cameras to work again. It's a shame, these used to work SO well.

Reviews.Title: Technical support was top notch!  The only down side was that I waited on hold for more than an hour for a representative.
Reviews.Author: KindOfKhaos "Travis"
Reviews.Content: Great camera.  Reasonable price.  Felix was an awful lot of help.  He helped me get my camera set up wirelessly as I was running into some difficulties and then helped me set up my camera so that I could access it remotely.  Very helpful!

Reviews.Title: Not the camera I wanted
Reviews.Author: Sharan H
Reviews.Content: I wanted to like this camera, it's inexpensive, and has a lot of features.  It comes short of what I needed.I turned on motion capture/alert.  When it gets dark, the photoresistor on the unit activates the IR for night mode.  When this happens, it triggers a false alert.  So basically, you are guaranteed 2 alerts every day, 1 at dawn and 1 at dusk.  This is extremely annoying.  There is no software fix for this, as Foscam wired the photoresistor completely independent of the programming logic, so this is really a hardware bug.My fix for this was to put tape over the photoresistor, this is the only way around this.If Foscam could fix this feature for me, I would give it 5 stars.The user interface is a little user unfriendly, and leaves something to be desired.  I'm an advanced user, but I can imagine the interface being quite daunting for a novice user.

Reviews.Title: Wireless Connection does not work!
Reviews.Author: Suzanne Blanchett
Reviews.Content: After trying many hours to get the Wireless connection to work and reading many other internet posts on trying to get it to work we have returned this product.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera, but warranty hell!
Reviews.Author: CamMBA
Reviews.Content: I bought 5 8910Ws.  After the steep learning curve, I successfully installed all 5 of them and I felt like king of the world!  However, about 3 months after purchase, one of the cameras stopped working and it's been warranty hell with Foscam ever since. No kidding, it's been 36 days since I first contacted Foscam about getting a replacement 8910W. Can you believe that it took them 12 days of back and forth -- 12 emails -- to simply authorize my return/replacement? And that was just the beginning! They got my broken camera on March 1st. Today is March 28th. They still haven't shipped my replacement -- 26 emails later -- they keep saying they will ship it and I keep asking for tracking info --- NOTHING.My other 4 cameras work great -- I love them -- but god forbid they should break while under 'warranty.' Buyer beware -- buying directly from Amazon.com (and not some shady 3rd party) won't save you from warranty hell!

Reviews.Title: No audio for mac users
Reviews.Author: Earl Ax
Reviews.Content: There is no direct option for audio for mac users.  Not using the webui, not using VLC, not using any other free apps I have found.  Some users have reported success with paid apps, but that's crazy.When that gets resolved I'll be happy with it for a baby monitor.The picture is clear for 640x480 -- it is what it is.  The night vision is good, the wifi range is better than expected.  The pan/tilt feature is novel (my previous cameras have all been stationary) and useful.I miss the on-screen display feature of other low-cost IP cameras I have used.  I also miss the integrated storage (or SD card) feature that would allow the motion alarm to record video clips.  As it is the system can only record a snapshot on alarm.  They system can also alarm on audio input, which is interesting, maybe useful (maybe not).Fix the audio problem and it'll be a four-star product, given the price.

Reviews.Title: The Foscams are virtually plug and play.  A quick setup while wired to the router and they're ready to go!
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "formerly a Road Warrior of t...
Reviews.Content: We bought several of these to use in protected outdoor locations to monitor some questionable activity around our home - we now have eyes outside when they think we're busy or not at home.  The Foscam is very easy to setup, we simply hooked it up to our router, configured a few settings and disconnected it from our router.  They were then ready to connect wirelessly to our network.  They've been running a few weeks now, very handy!  We have already spotted the culprit who has been throwing glass bottles at the fire hydrant (causing broken glass all around that area of our yard Grrr)  and found it useful to remotely monitor another situation. These cameras automatically switch to infrared in low light situations. The Foscam cameras automatically detected into our Mi Casa Verde home automation controller - the VeraLite, so I can view instant snips from my cell phone, even while away from home.  I have NOT had to use dynamicDNS, Mi Casa Verde handles everything necessary internally and automatically.  Sweet!

Reviews.Title: Great Video, Pain in the But to Setup
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Bought this as a Baby monitor. Based on reviews and features, I thought this was a great buy for the price. However, if you plan on wasting a few hours in setup and then waste another several hours to research on setup because the instructions are terrible (I regard myself as very proficient with tech items). After setup, I was able to see my little one! Great and perfect.... but, no audio (advertised function). Tried many configurations, adjusted the software, tested this and that but no audio via PC, IOS, MAC, etc. Either these are flakey in quality control but I got a crappy one and this was my second one to replace a previouse order. In addition, I keep hearing a clicking sound, which I found out that it was the IR "switch", OK, but it clicks (loud) on and off more than it should and even during bright daylight. I keep wondering if someone else is watching... Anyways, I returned them both. So in short video good (once past 4-8hrs setup), audio non existing, and poor quality control. Glad others are enjoying theirs, you were the lucky ones to get a functional one. If you want to try your luck, go on ahead, but I'm not trying again.

Reviews.Title: Good so far
Reviews.Author: ae in vir "ae in vir"
Reviews.Content: I've been using it for only a short time, but it's working well so far.  Getting it set up to work within our wireless network was a piece of cake.  Setting up port forwarding so that we can view from elsewhere was more difficult, but that was due to my own limitations.  A friend entered the settings in the router software in a few minutes.I'm able to access the camera from my laptop away from home and also from the CamViewer app on my iPhone.  The picture is clear and I'm able to see well even in complete darkness with IR turned on.Although I was able to follow the instructions in the manual, it is poorly written and could stand a good re-write.

Reviews.Title: Easy Setup
Reviews.Author: Daniel Parcher
Reviews.Content: For the folks here that are concerned about setup, it's pretty easy if you know how to use your router. Here's how it works:1) Toss the installation CD in the trash, it is basically only used to identify the IP that the camera is on (easy to figure out from your router)2) Plug the camera into your router using the ethernet cable (mine was provided)3) From a web browser type in the IP address the camera came up on (should be easy to find from your router's status page)4) From your web browser, you should now be able to tell the camera about your wifi network via the camera's configuration page.5) Unplug the ethernet cable and reboot the camera.6) From your router, grab the MAC address to the camera (now connected on wifi) and permanently assign it the IP it came up on7) If you have a domain set up, give the camera a name so that you don't have to remember the IP address. (optional)8) You can now put the name (or local IP) into your web browser whenever you want to access the camera.At this point you have the camera set up on your local network. You can add users, set passwords, etc. all from any internet browser on your local network. If you want to open up connections from outside your network (like, say from your phone over 3/4g), you need to establish port forwarding to the camera.Be aware that if you don't have a static IP from your ISP that your IP may change, and you may need to update it (via various methods, some of which can be automated) in order to access the camera from outside your local area network.It really is very straightfoward if you know how to use your router. If your router software is difficult to use (as mine was), flash your router with dd-wrt to make it useful.

Reviews.Title: Foscam Fi8910W
Reviews.Author: Allen
Reviews.Content: Product arrived as described. Appears to be built well. Had difficulty setting up-and a rep from Foscam (Simon) returned my call about 2 hours later and remotely set up the cameras for me. Thank you Simon!!!! Please note that this camera will require a power source (outlet). Also...it was fairly easy to get it up and running using the Cat5 cable (supplied). However, I spent over 2 hours trying to get the cameras to communicate with my modem before calling tech support...and then it was a 2 hour wait for callback. It will take "some doing" to do all the steps to make the cameras viewable from my Droid (port forwarding, etc.). Not a quick and simple process...therefore-please do your research and watch videos on Youtube before and after purchasing so you will have an idea of what you will need to do in order to get these to work for your particular application. The written instructions supplied (and the instructions on the included CD) are not as detailed as they should be. I actually purchased mine direct-and AFTER the technician solved my issues he asked if I was a member of Amazon and if so would I post an honest review-and thus I have. This is my first product review and I hope it will help someone.

Reviews.Title: Patience required
Reviews.Author: Charles L. Thomas "chuckerst"
Reviews.Content: After studying tutorials and trying for hours to view remotely (and pulling my hair out),I conceded defeat and was going to return the camera but decided,as a last straw to call customer support-I tried twice and was on hold 30 minutes so that pretty much settled it-one last attempt was to e-mail customer support-I shared my frustration and requested a call for help after 5:15-they emailed me back and said no problem some one would call-never expected a call but at exactly 5:15 a rather not really so friendly person called and got on my computer via remote access-he had me working in about 5 minutes! For some reason the port number I picked wouldn't work-he entered a different one and voila! the camera works perfectly and I can now monitor my residence perfectly from my work pc and/or iphone! Oh-and the camera is AMAZING in low light-couldn't be happier!

Reviews.Title: Works as advertised, I'm not sure what all the fuss is about...
Reviews.Author: Sandro Fouche
Reviews.Content: TL;DR version: Great price, works well, setup is easy enough for experienced users.We bought this to act as a internet-enabled baby monitor.  Devices with the same set of features but marketed for baby-cam use seem to run 2-3x as much, so the price made the Foscam Fl8910w seem like a real bargain.But with all the controversy about the reviews of this camera, I approached this purchase with a good deal of wariness.Some quick disclaimers, I'm a computer professional, and I have configured more than my fair share of web-enabled devices.That said, I found this network camera straight-forward to setup and get going.  It works as advertised with two-way audio quality well within the acceptable range, good video quality, and apparently free DynDNS service.The camera needs to be hooked up via Ethernet for it's initial configuration.  While this is a slight hassle, it makes getting the WiFi settings very easy.I'm a Mac user, and I usually expect a bit of hassle during setup.  I was surprised to see that the included software CD has a Mac setup utility.  I skipped using it since I hate cluttering up my machine with one-time use (possibly gimpy) software.  So I did the configuration "manually".  Once the camera was hooked up on my network, I found the address it was assigned on my router, and the remainder of the configuration is done on the built-in webserver.  I could immediately see the camera was working, and the pan/tilt functions performed as expected.  I had to setup the WiFi settings, and I checked out the dynamic DNS settings.The device comes with a dynDNS name assigned out of the myfoscam.org domain, which appears to be free and setup to work with the camera automagically.  I also enabled a third-party DynDNS service through no-ip.com, which I created an account and setup for the purpose of hooking to this camera.  Both seem to function fine, and I get the correct address through both services.Finally, uPNP wasn't working through my (Apple Airport) wireless router, so I added a port-forward/redirect for the camera to the network configuration on the router.Total setup time: 30 mins, including time to find and configure an iOS client.The image quality is very good, probably better than I've seen on any baby monitor, and the audio quality is clear and loud in both directions.  There is some "fisheye" distortion in the image, but I think that's a function of trying to get the widest coverage with the lens possible, and I can't really fault them for it.  The image is certainly good enough to see what's happening in a nursery.  The IR lights allow monitoring the room in the dark, and work extremely well.So I can say as a *real* customer who has never having dealt with Foscam support, I'm a happy camper so far.  Time will tell if this camera is reliable, but so far so good.

Reviews.Title: Foscam FI8910W IP Camera
Reviews.Author: Flying4905
Reviews.Content: OK - I'll try to keep this brief and hopefully will not cover too much of stuff that others have already covered. Here are my two cents:Camera and software is for the most part excellent (for the price).  It does the job as advertised.The setup to get the camera working on your local wireless network literally will take less than five minutes (even if you are not computer savvy).The setup to get the camera working OVER THE INTERNET can have some pitfalls if you get sidetracked - I'm going to give you some tips to avoid getting sidetracked - First - DO NOT try to follow the Youtube instructions, I think from Awkward Hamster - it's likely your router is not the same as his, and it's easy to get messed up trying to follow his instructions.  Another thing is this (and it's a big one) - DO NOT use the DynDNS service that everybody talks about - it's either no longer free, or they have become very good at hiding the free part of their service.  Something AwkwardHamster does not mention is that Foscam offers FREE DDNS service for three years, and it sets up completely automatically through the camera software - TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THIS.Here's how to avoid problems and get a quick internet connection setup for your FOSCAM camera - Two Ways:  One, there is a setup video on the CD that comes with the camera.  Follow this to the letter and it is very easy to set up the camera (although they push the DynDNS service for some reason, which baffles me, because you get three years of Foscam DNS FREE OF CHARGE). Also you have to suppress laughing at the horrible accent of the instructor.Secondly, if you can follow the written setup instructions that come with the camera ( I actually recommend this method ) - and they aren't too difficult - these actually walk you step by step through the entire setup process for the camera.And yes, once you do it a couple of times it is all easy as pie and it does work as advertised...Now, the caveat - I have a fair amount of computer experience and would probably be considered an expert by 90% of the computer public - but I tried setting up my camera system according to the Youtube videos, and ended up:  Crashing new Windows 8 computer (had to do a Restore on it); crashing Belkin N dual band router (had to do a Restore to Factory Default); did some goofy stuff to my DSL modem re: the internet connection - and a couple of other weird things...Either follow the video setup instructions or the written setup instructions that come with the camera and you will be fine. Don't be intimidated and if you get stuck or something goes wrong just keep trying and you will get it to work (I got really messed up and just kept working it until I got it up and running, I never called Foscam help or any of that)...

Reviews.Title: Fun watching the dog and cat fight
Reviews.Author: James Whitmoyer
Reviews.Content: This was really easy to set up, and we did the whole internet connection thing. That was a little more technical to set up, but worth it. We log in when travelling to check on things, and we often see the dog laying on the couch (bad dog!).The ability to remotely control it from a iPhone is great.

Reviews.Title: Every small business needs to have one or more of these.
Reviews.Author: Braath Waate
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera after a trusted employee was suspected of theft at the cash register.  The method of theft was to ring up a sale, and if the customer paid cash with exact change and did not request a receipt, the employee would later pocket the money and cancel the sale.  This way there was no record of the transaction and the cash drawer would reconcile at the end of the day.As others have mentioned, the foscam camera was incredibly easy to install.  Just attach a ethernet line, look at the router to find the IP address assigned by the router, and use a web browser to configure.  The camera can then be mounted anywhere near a power outlet.  My camera is mounted about six feet above the cash register, which gives me enough scope to monitor a transaction to make sure that cash makes it into the drawer.I have a 24x7 ubuntu computer that has an ftp server.  The camera was set to store to this server (FTP Server Settings) and to upload every second after motion was triggered (Alarm Service Settings).  I wrote a simple shell script to archive the activity on a daily basis and remove files older than a month.  To review the day's activity (this takes maybe 10 minutes, depending on the amount of activity), I use the ubuntu command "feh -D 0.25 [files]".  To monitor the area in realtime, I use totem "[camera ip address]/videostream.asf?user=admin&pwd;=" rather than a web browser, because I found that the web browser uses much more cpu.There is room for improvement.  Sound is pretty horrible.  I would also like a slightly faster upload interval (maybe 0.5 sec rather than 1 second, but the foscam does not support it).

Reviews.Title: Glad I rolled the dice, works great.
Reviews.Author: Trevor P.
Reviews.Content: I had some trepidation on buying these due to some of the negative reviews but I proceeded for two reasons: 1. I like to think I can figure out most tech things if given enough time and I have Google available to help troubleshoot my questions. 2.  If it didn't work, I knew it would be an easy return to Amazon.I ordered 3 cameras and also ordered Foscam Blue Iris software.  I used the install disc that came with Camera #1.  It was really simple.  I followed the instructions and it worked both with my ethernet and with my wireless network.  Changed the port settings per the instructions and no problems there either.  My IP is static, so I didn't have to go through those issues.My only cons were I could not get it to work with Chrome, which is my preferred browser.  Worked fine with all three cams on IE.  This won't really be an issue in the future as I'm using Blue Iris to monitor it from my PC and then IP Cam Viewer ($3.99) on my android applications.  Blue Iris is not really that intuitive at first, but the help section really lays out all you need. Although this is not a review of that software, I bring it up because it is basically my interface, recording, viewing, etc., so it obviously is key to having a good experience with the cameras.The video quality is good in both light and dark.  You can adjust a lot of the settings for how choppy it will be, brightness, contrast, etc.  It is more than enough for me considering the price.  Maybe I got lucky, but I would give it a shot and see if you do too.  I cannot comment on how helpful customer support may or may not be, as I fortunately set up everything this evening in a couple hours.My wife is already rolling her eyes because I excitedly showed her an email alert with a motion triggered screenshot.  :)  My only major complaint: 2 days after I bought three of these the price dropped twenty bucks.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for the money.
Reviews.Author: John
Reviews.Content: For what this camera cost (got on lightning deal), I don't think it can be beat.I followed the set-up instructions exactly as stated in the included printed manual and the camera was running via my wireless network in 10-15 minutes.Port forwarding was no problem for me as my router set it up automatically (uPnP).  I have Win7 PC and Fios Router.I did update the camera web interface sfw, which improved accessing it via PC, but ruined accessing it via my blackberry.  I completely lost access via my blackberry.  So this was upsetting, but it was never that great anyway.On my Kindle Fire (android device) I downloaded tinyCam Monitor and it works great for viewing the camera.  Way better than the web interface included with the camera via Internet browser.  I only have the free version right now, which is limiting, but I will be buying the full version.The camera works great.  The Night Vision works excellent - can see clearly in pitch black.  The sound works great as well, much more clear than my baby monitor!  I have not tried speaking to the camera yet.  So I'm not sure how well this works.Overall I'm very pleased with the camera and I ordered a second one that should arrive this week!

Reviews.Title: Great IP Camera!
Reviews.Author: Todd Joyce "The SpaGuru"
